reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me qualify here, I like this game quite a bit and I think it does deserve all the praise it recieved. So why the negative review? Well for one, Steam doesn't give me the option to have a neutral review, and two I want to give potential buyers some reasons as to why they wouldn't want to buy in. Most of the negative reviews don't really do that, at least not in detail.

I've been following this game for a long time, a lot of love has gone in to its development, and it really shows through the quirky spritework. The problem with the development is that it's just been so painfully slow that I can't recommend spending $15 on it at this point, because the desire to check back in after a few months when nearly nothing new has been added fades away after over two years; and that's how long I've had this game. It was first released for beta purchase around April 1, 2014.

Over the course of two years, the story has essentially gained one new dungeon (of which there was only one before) along with a marginal amount of content that shows this game is going to be in development for many more years. The content that's there is good, sure, but it's not so stellar as to justify playing through the story more than once or twice.

The real mode that seems to add playtime to this game is its arcade mode, which is roguelike in nature, and requires a good understanding of enemy/boss patterns to do well in. Players play through two floors representing each area in the story mode, complete with enemies from said area, and have no chances to heal except at the end of each floor. Despite having numerous floors and all of the enemies from the story mode, it's pretty light on content in terms of roguelikes. There are unlockables and such, but they only give minor advantages, and as a result adding more floors to the mode seems kind of pointless in its current state. Even after over two years of going back to this game I struggle to reach the 7th floor of what must be over 14 at this point. There isn't much incentive to bother trying to reach those floors either.

So should you buy this game? Well that depends on how patient you are. After two years I'm pretty burned out and don't see myself playing this game for a long, long time. If you think you can wait for what could be 5 years to play a finished product and want to support the developers, then by all means get this game. If not, keep an eye on it and pick it up a few years down the road when it has a more justifiable amount of content to offer.

Edit: Thanks for all the support guys, since this review got so much attention I want to add a little more.

If you're worried about spending $15 on a game that won't be finished, don't be. This game is a safe buy in my opinion. Even though the development has been very slow, it has been extremely consistent and the team behind this game definitely has what it takes to finish the job. Secrets of Grindea has been in the works since 2011, and the quality of the content in it has only improved since. Their dev blog[www.secretsofgrindea.com] has a weekly recap that is posted nearly every week without missing a beat. So if you're interested, definitely keep an eye on this game, because it is one of the better early access titles out there, despite the slow development speed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start off by saying if you think this game doesn't have grinding in it...then seek help. There are people who care about you and don't wish to see you go down this path (not me per se, we've only just met. But I'm sure there are people who love you very much. Like your grandmother or that neighbor with the nice rack. Anyway, I'm going off topic here).

Secrets of Grindea is a tongue-in-cheek RPG that draws heavily on the nostalgia of games like Secrets of Mana, Zelda: Link to the Past, and Illusion of Gaia. The sprite animations and colorful backgrounds mimic classic 16-bit games and go well with the fluidity of combat. NPCs are prevalent in towns and in the overworld to the point where the world does not feel empty and that their character is not some lone warrior living on a planet full of monsters (though that sounds like an awesome game idea. Dibs). Each area has its own unique feel that you will hopefully enjoy because the aforementioned grinding will have you staying in one area killing the same enemies for drops.

The combat is extremely straight forward where your basic attack is spamming one button or having a charged skill where you hold and release one button. Let me go on record to say that I do not think this is a bad thing. Sure, you won't be chaining attacks that culminate in your wooden sword hitting with the power of a tactical nuclear device, but you will be unlocking and upgrading skills that define the way you, the player, wish to play. The skills are limited (for now I hope) to a 1 handed skill set, 2 handed skill set, and a magic skill set. The player is able to mix and match these skills however he or she wants and has the option to refund some or all of the skill points that were spent by spending gold (this is done in the menu rather than with an NPC). There is a bow the player can get from a sidequest but so far doesn't have a dedicated set of skills to leveling up the damage.

The story is pretty straightforward for an RPG of the era it emulates: You are a guy or gal that wakes up, is handing a magical bag that can hold anything without weight restrictions and are sent out to become a renowned member of the Collectors". It seems
recommended: that these "Collectors" are a bunch of people that go out and collect cool
hoursPlayed: rare things. It is all very prestigious. And dangerous. And sexy. Seriously
voteText: so far every NPC that isn't a Collector is jealous of you. Normally one would have to buy seven sports cars and have an attractive life mate to get that kind of recognition. This game hands that to you right off the bat (Disclaimer: The developers of this game will NOT buy you cars nor introduce you to hot people for a hook up).\n\nMy main concern with the game is that it seems too short and I say that knowing full well that not all the features in the game have been implemented; this is not the reason that I feel the game is too short. The in-game journal keeps a record of all the enemies in the game and what they drop when killed. Enemies you haven't killed yet appear in the journal as silhouettes. Upon counting (yes
helpfulPercent: I did a math) I found that there are only about thirty (30) enemies total in the game including boss enemies. This
votesHelpful: in my opinion
votesTotal: is a low number which may make gamers shy away from the game. An increase in not just the number of potential enemies but different types of enemies will add more variety to the grinding while still keeping the player's interest high. I eagerly await the areas that have not yet been implemented to the game.\n\nNow
votesFunny:
I'm not going to end this review by giving the game a number based off of 5 nor 10 nor 325745456415 (<--- not sure what this number is. It just punched my Numpad to come up with something ridiculous). I will end this review with just a few simple words:

I enjoy this game.



I hope you enjoy it too."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Where to begin.  This game is as advertised.  It's a game similar to Secret of Mana (SNES), Crystalis (NES), Zelda-esque, Final Fantasy Adventure (Original GB)  and many other old RP games.

You can customize your character physically by gender, colour of your clothes, hair style and colour, and name.  Additonally, you get a vanity part for your hat, face, weapon, and shield.

The gameplay is very nice, you can be a full warrior, full mage, whatever you want to be; a combination if you want.  Although, being a healer is not an option.

This is a beta game, it's not complete, from my estimation it's a little near half done, if that.

You can play cooperatively, over the internet, using your steam friends list or direct IP!  This is awesome!

You grind in the game, if that wasn't obvious.  (What old school console RPG didn't have you grind?  It's part of the fun!)

The transition between keyboard and controller playing is seamless, you just start using your keyboard and it swaps to keyboard mode, you use your controller, it swaps to controller mode.  I found this particularly great!

The host of the game's save file is progressed in the story, however - if you're not the host - you keep everything you gained.  You simply have to play through the story (by hosting or single player) to go through it.  The rewards though, you do not acquire again, you already have them!  :D

This is an awesome game!  As far as I'm aware only three people are working on it and they're from Sweden.  They have me as a fan.  The sprite animation is awesome, the artwork for the avatars is great and expresses much emotion, and the game looks very polished for a beta that is not even half done!

I used to pay $50+ US dollars for games like these, and wait years for the next to come out.  I love the game very much, and I haven't even started exploring the Arcade Mode.

tl;dr - Buy this game if you loved Secret of Mana or any similar games on the console or PC.  Especially if you want to play it co-op with friends over the internet!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To review this game is to review it in two parts.

Story Mode: An amazing adventure akin to the days of Secret of Mana, Sword of Mana and Seiken Densetsu 3. Quick swordplay with an oldschool-meets-polish aesthetic that's filled with charm. Combat is quick paced and - with over 20 skills and spells with multiple charge levels, along with 30 talents - more or less unique for every character made. Every attack, skill and spell feels as if it has weight behind it for a thoroughly satisfying brawl through hordes of monsters and challenging bosses.

The story is serious at times, tongue in cheek in others without outright resorting to cheese. There's plenty of side-quests, mini-games and collectables, but contrary to the name no grinding appears to be necessary. The shield is as relevant to the gameplay as the sword is, every attack can be blocked if you know the exact timing, reminding me of the days of 'Timed Hits' from Super Mario RPG and Final Fantasy 8.

The music is beautiful, the characters well written to make you love or hate them, I can't say enough good things about Story Mode. The only shame is it's incomplete, but between pet taming, treasure hunting, fishing, card collecting, playing with 4 player online co-op and duking it out in the arena, there's more than enough content to keep me busy between updates.

Arcade Mode: All the rules from Story Mode no longer apply, Arcade Mode feels like an entirely different game. Less Secret of Mana, more Binding of Isaac. You start in an empty plain and delve within a randomized roguelike-esque labyrinth. Each room is different every time, filled with traps and all manners of enemies or bosses not present in Story Mode. HP is precious, mastery of skills, spells and shielding is required.

Arcade Mode is perfect for sinking endless hours into as you try to go deeper and deeper into the labyrinth, gaining points and essence to level up and expand your town, unlock new NPCs to aid you, take on quests for rare and unique loot not found anywhere else. Skills and spells are best experimented with in here to see which build suits you best. With friends it's harder, but with 4 people on screen the monsters barely stand a chance once you hit your groove. The online leaderboards for Arcade Mode help to give it even more replay value by trying to do better than your friends or complete strangers to try and hit #1.

If you have any doubts whatsoever, try the demo. With an hour of Story Mode gameplay, several hours of Arcade Mode and co-op bundled into the demo, it's a great teaser for what to expect moving forward.

Tip: Opt into 'Frontline' by selecting SoG in your library if you want quicker updates. The normal version receives slower updates, but your experience in the game will be much smoother.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is based on the game in its current state at the time of posting and is completely my opinion. Yours may differ to mine. I also only really played the story mode and did co-op.
Secrets of Grindea is an action RPG with a major focus on the story and meticulous detail worked into its environments and graphics.

I just completed everything in the Secrets of Grindea that is currently available in the version out at this time and I have to say that what they have so far is fan-bloody-tastic.

Things I liked
Fantastic pixel graphics with fluid animations that make me say wow" in some circumstances
An interesting story with creative sidequests and lovely characters
Hats and lots of them. I'm a Team Fortress 2 man and I found the choice of hats to be most adequate.
The plethora of references. I won't spoil any of them
date:
but they're there.
The soundtrack consisted of fantastic tracks that all matched their locations in game. Not a single track sounded out of place in this game.
Things I didn't like all that much
The story was a bit short. But that can be attributed to the fact that it's in early access.
The limited supply of weapons available was quite disheartening as I found myself wielding the most powerful one-handed sword in the game about 1/2 of the way through the story with not much choice on what else to use.
Player customzation is unfortunately incredibly limited with the only changable things being colour of clothing

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has driven me to make my first serious review about a game, ever.

This game is one of the most satisfying RPG experiences I have ever had, ranking above many AAA games.
Everything about this game brings about an intense craving to  play more  in the best possible way.

Pros:
Combat
-Large skill tree filled with unique and interesting abilities.
-If you like an ability you can level it up over time to make that ability do more awesome stuff
-The freedom to mix melee / ranged spells to create a unique playstyle
-Epic and highly original bosses that are frequent and challenging

The Story and Regions
-Colorful and vibrant art style with very well done sound effects
-Likeable characters and lighthearted approach make for an enjoyable story with a mysterious undertone
-Main quests take you to several areas that are have their own unique themes and enemies
-Regions are fairly large with explorable secrets and puzzles containing hidden loot

Loot and Cards
-The everpresent chance of obtaining cards" is one that creates the urge to grind each area's different enemies
-Not only do enemies drop cards they drop crafting materials as well as rare and unique equipable gear to further create incentive to grind

THE DEVS!
-The trio over at Pixel Ferrets are incredibly talented and hard working
-Weekly dev blog updates along with frequent patches add tons of content at a high rate
-Buy them coffee to add hyperspeed perk to your favorite dev team

Other Pros:
-Easy to connect multiplayer supporting up to 4 people
-Well done controller support
-A talking bag that roasts people

Cons:
-Smallish amount of craftable material (But of course more will be added over time)
-Some bosses are way harder than others on the hard difficulty (perhaps need more difficulty settings?)

As an early access review the full potential of this game has yet to be realized however; this game has so much personality
date:
tied with a fun combat system and an enjoyable playthrough experience making for a game that has a lot to give.
This game is growing fast so you'll always be able to come back and enjoy more of the world of Grindea!
I would highly reccommend that you purchase this game if you love RPG's because this RPG is every gamers wet dream.
"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Story-wise, it's nothing special. The story is well-written, funny at times, but ultimately nothing that will win any prizes.
Action-wise, it's nothing special. Combat systems and skill trees reminiscient of soo many other games of the same kind.
Visuals are not really anything special either. Everything is cute and well-made, like in so many other games of the same kind.

But you know what? It's engaging, it's fast-paced, it's completely glitch-free and smooth, and most importantly it supports multiplayer through Steam. It's both a relaxing and fast-paced Action RPG that I can definitely recommend that you enjoy with a friend or two. Not to mention it is still in Early Access, which means there's lots of content to still come.

So far, this game is extremely well-made and polished, and definitely something you can sink some time into, alone or not; though the multiplayer aspect was ultimately what made me buy it. I haven't tried the arcade mode yet, but I already feel I've seen enough of this game to recommend it dearly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been waiting for a game like this for YEARS.

Zelda/ Ys meets Castlevania, with a story like something out of SNES-era JRPGs.

Grindea doesn't take itself too seriously, but really hits home with amazing sprite animations, exeptionally tight and ballanced gameplay, a loot/crafting system that makes you actually want to collect things you don't need, and a simple, yet complex level up system that honestly doesn't feel like any I've seen before, and to top it off, it's got a killer hard mode (arcade mode) that reminds me why I suck at rouguelikes, yet for some reason keep coming back to them!

Oh, AND it's got a great coop system! My gf and I look for fun coop games pretty frequently, and we're often dissapointed. Not this time! Great weekend gaming/ veg session!

The only gripe I have, is that since it's early access, the adventure content is incomplete. It took the two of us about 14 hours to complete" the story at 100%. Arcade mode had more stuff
date: but was a little too punshing for us to experiment much.  I need the rest of that story!\n\nSeriously. Buy this game. At full price."

OBS!!! FOR THOSE WHO ARE INTERESTED IN LOCAL CO-OP!!
There is just one little thing that made me frustrated. That is how to fix the Local Co-op mode. I had to search around a bit until I found it. You have to download something called steam_appid.txt which you can find on this link down here: (file is from a staff member called Teddy)

http://secretsofgrindea.com/forum/index.php?threads/local-co-op-on-2-computers.913/

Put it in the ...Steam\steamapps\common\SecretsOfGrindea folder. Then you have to run 2 windows at one time and do some other things in order to make each controller locked for each window you opened. You'll find more out on the steps that you will be following in the guide on that page!

It works really good when you get everything to work! I play on two different monitors at the same time, my laptop screen and TV screen using HDMI cable. Works really well! You can also have two windows running in a single monitor ofc, or 4 windows if you would like that. It has its cons and pros ofc.

GL & HF!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I hate grinding. I really do. But not in this game as the grinding is rewarding and the battle system is a lot of fun.

YOU DON'T HAVE TO GRIND - BUT YOU'LL WANT TOSecrets of Grindea is a 2D Action-RPG with roots in the SNES-era ARPG games such as the Mana-series and Legend of Zelda. The battles are fast and the basics are quite easy to learn. You can't just button smash your way through though. The system is very much reliant on your skills and strategies, despite the fact that you can grind for levels to overpower yourself.

The beauty of the game is that you don't have to grind an excessive amount of time, but often you'll want to. If you just want to enjoy the story and explore the world, you can advance fairly quickly through the story. Boss battles are often very tough if you're underleveled but with a correct strategy, they are very beatable without power grinding. You unlock new areas to explore by advancing the story and you are free to roam the areas you've unlocked. The enemies are visible on the map and they are all avoidable.

A 2D SANDBOX WITH TON OF STUFF TO DOFor the completionists, there is a ton of optional things to do. There's fishing, potion-making, side-quests, secrets, puzzles, pet catching, pet leveling, arena-battles, crafting and a ton of mob drops that are hard to get. I myself have already spend at least 2 times more than my Steam play-time shows in this game, doing all the optional stuff. That was over a year ago when there wasn't this much new content in it yet.

The leveling system is very nice since you get points to spend on skills as you please. There is a good amount of different skills to choose from and all of them have strategic value. There is also a lot of different equipment which you can buy, craft or get as a drop from the monsters.

YOU DON'T PLAY POKEMON-GAMES FOR THEIR STORYThe story isn't awful either. It's not the focus of the game nor the main reason to buy the game. It has enough meat in it to keep you motivated to go further and to give some context to your adventure but don't expect it to move you to tears or grab you emotionally. Think Pokemon games and their story and you'll know what level of story-telling to expect.

As a big fan of stories and powerful story-telling in games, I would've wanted a more compelling story-telling personally but because of the strong gameplay, the lack of PSX-era Final Fantasy-esque story telling doesn't bother me much at all.

TOO LONG, DIDN'T READAll in all, this has been my #1 most anticipated indie-game since 2013, when I bought the pre-order beta. SoG is a a good balance of excellent gameplay, exploration and story. While the story is not up to par with the gameplay, the complete package is still excellent and the 3 Swedish Stooges can be proud of what they've been working on for all these years.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are looking for a game to evoke your memories of childhood, this is it.  Secrets of Mana was bar none my favorite game on the SNES.  Nothing I have played since gives quite the same feeling of grinding on rabites for hours on end to build weapon skills.

Not only does Grindea have a similar battle system, but it adds several customization options, from combat skills to magic to costumes, it also adds puzzle elements and arcade modes for further challenge.  The rare loot drops keep you farming mobs and bosses, and for the meta meta minded, there are card drops from in game enemies, in game achievements, Steam achievements, and presumably down the road, Steam cards.  It's a total overload of gathering meta!

If I had to pick some complaints about the game, here they are:

Arcade mode - I'm not patient enough, and never get passed the first or second stage.  Gimme a heal, dammit.

Greenlight - It took way too long to get Greenlight, dammit.

Development time - Stalking the devblog gets old after a while.  It has been way too long a wait for the complete game, dammit.

I might have an issue with patience.

Do yourself a favor, if you ever enjoyed overhead Nintendo games, support the devs, give this a shot.  It's only an amazing themesong and a fuzzy sprite away from being a classic.

Also, hats.  That is all.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a zelda-eqse play-with-your-friends 8 bit RPG + an additional mode where you can play it as a roguelike with your friends. It's incredibily polished and the combat system is well refined and requires more timing and depth than other games of the same genre. While some of the ways to beat the bosses are cliche, this is not necessarily a downside because they are splendidly executed. Furthermore, there are a fair amount of bosses whose patterns/attacks the developers have taken creative liberty to make unique, unexpected, and enjoyably difficult. Characters are not class bound; rather each character has a limited number of usuable skill points and the same pool of skills they can choose from. This allows for multiple unique playthroughs on both story and arcade (roguelike) mode. I haven't found a similar game that brings forth the amount of depth, polish and nostalgia that Grindea has.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have over 100 hours pumped into the game [if you include the pre-steam access] and this is one of my favorite games of all time.

Pros:
- Typical story, but hilarious dialog, fun characters and environmental/discovery-based story telling makes it a great experience.
- Super deep and rewarding combat system with a plethora of skills and mechanics to master such as the perfect guard.
- Enemies and bosses attack differently between normal and hard mode, as well as single or multiplayer
- Skill charging makes it so you have almost 3 different skills at your disposal despite leveling only one skill.
- Loads of side quests, mini games and discoveries to be found.
- Multiplayer with up to 4 players that is super smooth gameplay-wise. Connection is also easy via Steam friend list.
- Gorgeous pixel art that contains many little details to make the game world feel alive.
- Music fits each area very well and does not overstay its welcome at all.
- Arcade (roguelite) mode adds a ton of replayability. Beating it is hard enough, the side roguelite quests and high score chasing allows infinite replayability.

Cons:
- Non-hosts may experience lag, which ruins the multiplayer experience [case-by-case basis]
- Would be nice for some skills to interact with each other more for multiplayer mayhem [Earth spike wall + Smash?]

For a detailed full impressions video [8 minutes long], check out this video below!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IE9YK0uO0nY

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Admittedly, I went into this game not knowing much about it at all, which is somewhat rare for me in this day and age. I did this because I felt I didn't need to know much about the game, my very first impression from the trailer and a youtube video sold me on the spot. And I can say, roughly 9 hours into the game as of this review, that my first impression was spot on. If you enjoy the classic action RPGs of the 1990's and early 2000's, such as Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past, Illusion of Gaia, or (obviously) Secret of Mana, then this game is for you and is well worth your time, money, and intrigue.

From my perspective, this game offers 4 distinct areas of interest that define the experience:
Story Mode
Arcade Mode
Multiplayer
The Progression System (Skills and Talents) I will be covering all 4, explaining my experiences and impressions of each.

STORY MODEWhile a bit lacking in the engaging story aspect, Secret of Grindea's (SoG) Story Mode offers something many RPGs have failed to have for a while now: the elegance of simplicity. Many modern titles have an obsession with creating a novel's worth of narrative. Cutscene after cutscene, wall of text after wall of text, the experience of these titles are moreso about the story and presentation of it than the actual game.

SoG takes the short and simple approach, where it gives enough story and narrative to provide context and motivation, but is spaced well enough where it does not feel like a chore to read through it all (having the option to skip cutscenes helps too). Not to say that the story isn't interesting, though. While simple and somewhat of a parady of other RPGs, many of the characters are likeable in their own right and their clever interactions are both entertaining and humurous. It's clear a lot of heart was put into the devolpment of this game from all of the silly and minor references to other games and characters.

Putting aside the storytelling aspect of SoG, there's quite a bit of content packed into what is currently available (game is still in beta as of this review). From collectables, to crafting, to minigames, puzzles, Zelda-esque dungeons, side quests, arena challenges, and engaging and replayable boss fights, there's a lot to do. But my favorite aspects are the inclusion of a genuinely difficult hard mode that can be toggled on or off at any time and the ability to customize the look of your character in the form of hats and accessories (that override the look of your currently equipped armor).

To review:

Pros:
Simple but effective narrative
Interesting and humurous dialogue
Plethora of activities, side quests, and minigames
Interesting boss fights
Hard Mode
Cons:
Game not complete (with no ETA)
ARCADE MODEArguably, this is where most of your time will go. This mode is SoG's roguelike feature, where you attempt to progress as far as you can through a serious of increasingly challenging rooms and obstacles on a single life. Much in the way of other roguelikes (such as Rogue Legacy), you have the ability the make succeeding runs easier in the form of unlocking perks. These are unlocked via a currency you obtain randomly as a drop and from completing quests and achievments.

The farther you go and the better you do, the more points you will recieve. After each death, your points are tallied up and added to your total score across all games. After certain thresholds have been met, you will revieve rewards, such as cosmetics (hats and accessories), more NPCs to interact with, and more buildings/decorations for your hub. There is also a global leaderboard for the mode, so if you're into that sort of thing you can sate your fancy here.

As for the actual content of the mode, it's challenging but rewarding. Like any other roguelikes, there are a lot of elements of randomness involved. The dungeon layout, challenges in each room, and the loot you get are all up to chance. However, this works as the combat system is based on skill moreso than raw stats. You will get farther in the dungeon because you got better rather than because you got some good luck on your drops. You find that you are excited to get as far as you can as that shows just how much better you got at the game more than anything else.

Pros:
Unlockable Perks
Achievments
Leaderboard
Replayability
Cons:
Can have a somewhat harsh learning curve
Can feel repetative at times
Like story mode, not all of the floors are implemented yet.
MULTIPLAYERWhile I have no personal experience with this feature myself, I have seen examples of this in videos and streams. From what I have seen, multiplayer is fairly smooth and simple to do. Multiplayer is available for both Story Mode and Arcade Mode, so if you have a group of friends you can enjoy all aspects of the game together with up to 4 people.

Be that as it may, it's not perfect. Currently, there is no option to play with your friends locally. You will need to connect to each other through different computers, and each person will need to have a copy. Additionally, it lacks some quality of life functions such as being able to join someone from your friends list. And, as one would expect from online play, there can exist some connection issues and bugs (although I've yet to see any).

Pros:
Can play with up to 4 people
Can play in both Story Mode and Arcade Mode
Smooth and stable online play
Cons:
Can have some connection issues and bugs
Lacks QoL polish
No Local Play
SKILLS AND TALENTSAn RPG needs to have some form of progression, and SoG does it with it's ability system. What makes this one stand out from the rest is its simplicity and its lack of restrictions. There are no skill trees, no level/stat requirements, you just choose the skills you like and roll with it. And so much is added to this game because of it.

There are a varity of skills that appeal to all forms of play, be it aggressive, defensive, evasive, melee, range, single target, AoE, Burst, DoT, etc. And given the lack of restrictions on obtaining skills, you can create a massive amount of different and interesting builds. Want to be an aggressive and fast melee striker? Go for it. Want to be a long-ranged magic nuker? Sure! Want to combine both melee and magic for a hybrid spellsword? That's cool too.

Additionally, a lot of the skills from different branches work well together. For instance, Static shock is a spell that will do additionally damage very time you hit with a physcial attack. You can restore charges for this skill from using physical skills or doing perfect guards, meaning this skill can be used in all kinds of builds, both offensive and defensive.

While I would argue a need for more skills, the simplicity of the current design is also appealing and useful. While some talents prove to be more useful than others, many of the skills have their uses and can work well given the right circumsances.

In the end, what gives this game a lot of replayability, both in Story Mode and in Arcade Mode, is the progression system and the appeal of trying out new builds and tactics.

Pros:
Non-restrictive
Skills work well together
Interesting and thoughtful effects
Easy to make and try new builds and tactics
Simple and easy to understand
Cons:
Some talents not as useful as others
Arguably not enough skills to facilitate variety

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For some odd reason, the game reminds me a lot of Paper Mario for the N64. I'm not exactly sure why... there's hardly any similarities.

I tried the demo of this game (lead up to the arena fight), and it had me sold. I was hesitant to buy it at the time, on sale, or was released... the formar took over (and I'm glad, worth every $ and then some). This game just... pulls me in and refuses to let go. I have to pry myself away from the game! (or till I feel my bladder being full to the brim...)

I picked hard difficulty as normal felt... easy for me... I have completely underestimated hard difficulty than I usually do for RPG games! At first I thought the game was just a collection of popular and maybe hardly used RPG tropes... well I'm not completely wrong. The story in the game is... interesting to say the least (up to what I reached)... at least I think there's a story? Somewhere? Maybe I overlooked it half way...

The game does encourage AND reward you for grinding/farming. I've noticed several times the spawn rate increases if it registers you grinding/farming, unlike other RPGs the spawn rate will decrease and/or would spawn mobs elsewhere instead of the spot you're on. (Looking at you MMORPG's... especially the F2P ones...) For some reason... grinding/farming isn't so trivial or boring than other games. Probably because I'm not seeing high leveled players showing me up one-hitting everything while I'm struggling (Always saw that as bad form) or the struggle isn't worth it.

Some of the mobs I feel move a bit too fast for hard mode. Strong, more HP, and additional moves I understand but... some just don't pause at all. Rather have the mobs pause less than in Normal than not pausing at all. Be nice if mobs had a weakness and resistance. Having a hard time just trying to kill them with no disadvantages.

The boss fights... either the bosses need a little tweaking, the leveling system needs bit of a fix, and/or the skills need to be reworked. There's been a few boss fights that nearly made me just go to normal difficulty (I had to temporary for the sentry mini-boss due to the stupid orbs!) Either too much is going on for me to register what's happening, I'm unable to get strong enough to properly face this boss/foe, and/or the skills I have are weak than they should be.

I've nearly crafted every item on the current list... on bit of a card hunt now. See cards as a reward for grinding/farming excessively as they give you benefits whether to your stats or purchases (that I've seen so far). Wish leveling actually increased your stats than just give you points to spend... I shouldn't feel so weak than I should be for (current) end-game bosses (toward Winter, Hydras, Toy Machine, etc.). Granted it's hard, but shouldn't be dark-souls difficult! (That's what it felt like most of the time after the numerous times of being frustrated at bosses to the point of nearly tossing my laptop out the one story window!!!)

Pick this up at its price of $15. Shouldn't wait for a sale, unless you're low on cash, to enjoy this. If you rather play a finished product than in development, then you'll be waiting for quite some time. Half of the story content is in the stable beta right now.

I'll most likely either update or completely rewrite this review when the game is finished. I think I'll wait till this game is finished before I continue any further in the story though.

Update: Tried a bit of Arcade Mode... it's not very forgiving that it discourages me. Reminds me of Rogue Legacy but harsher...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a Early Access game this is highly impressive. For one the amount of effort and polish here is staggering. Spritework is very detailed and charming and the animations are top notch all around. NPCs don't just sit around, they walk, talk, sneeze, cough, sigh, eat some chicken, work and more. They are all doing something and each one feels unique and goes a long way to draw you into the game world.

The gameplay is very tight and responsive. You have a robust amount of options when it comes to combat style thanks to weapon skills and various schools of magic. Specialize or mix and match, its all up to you and the game encourages it. The option to buy back level up points is a nice feature if not pricey.

The game also has tons of great design choices. Puzzle challenges let you rewind various steps of the puzzle. Pushed a block in the wrong space? No problem, step on a tile to undo it without having to reset the whole thing. And that feature is nice cause these puzzles can rack your brain on occasion. When it comes to crafting you can pin recipes your working on to your hud so you can know what you need at all times. Tons of smart game design on display here.

And not to mention the games Arcade mode which honestly could have been a whole game by itself. Its a permadeath roguelike style experience which asks you to go into randomly generated dungeons to rack up as many points as possible in one run by not only clearing rooms but being smart and quick about it. These points go towards improving your hub town. You can also find special rare items you can cash in for permanent perks that carry over from character to character. Also this whole game has 4 PLAYER ONLINE CO-OP! For Story AND Arcade mode with various features that go with that too like competitive minigames.

My mind is blown that this is a Early Access game cause good lord its already far acceded its asking price for me. Get a copy or two for your buddies and enjoy some good old fashioned action RPG goodness. ^^

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSecrets of Grindea is a game I have been looking forward to since I saw it on steam greenlight years ago. This game harkens back to a simpler gaming era; a time where the games had story, very fun fighting mechanics and a sense of completion and fulfillment. A few minor bugs here and there, considering it's still in its baby beta stage and maybe a few issues with enemies being overpowered in their crow control on players. This game is everything I've been wanting out of games today and just haven't been getting. As a future video game designer, Secrets of Grindea has the formula I've been looking for and want to perfect in making a game. I've gotten well over $15 worth of enjoyment out of this game and it's not even fully done yet. Hats off to the developers. 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first saw this game I thought it was some JRPG a game focused on story with little gameplay but it would make up for that with how extensive the customization is. I figured 17.00$ for a unfinished game might not be worth it even if it is good because it is still in early access and would have so little to the game that it is not worth it. The game looked like a higher quality indie maker game and that was not what I was interested in so I dismissed it. I wanted something that will have lots to do good gameplay and lots of replay value.

I was really wrong about the game. It is so good it is a contender to be one of my favorite games of all time. The game has great replay value, online multilayer, great combat, the fishing mini game is actually okay and it has a interesting but overall funny story that is skipable.

This game have great replay value there are many different monsters that can drop up to 4 different items when you defeat them, some are crafting items sometimes you can get some armor, a sword or a shield. Sometimes you need to gather crafting items to craft a new item or you can just find a new hat, sword if you kill enough monster that drop items. You can play the game with 4 players making the game harder the more people that play but the game is still fun to play because you can spend time focusing on collecting all the items in the game. I have almost played the game over 24 hours and I still have not gathered all the items, cards, achievement and even finished the story. You can change the game from easy to hard in the middle of the game making it very fair. The game has replay value because you could replay the game to have a magic user build otr a melee user build or something like that.

The gameplay is fun there is normal and hard difficulty hard adds a few more monsters to the levels makes them more aggressive, faster and stronger. The magic in the game is fair and not overpowered like it is in other games. You have powerful magic but summoning a monster reduces your energy while your summoned monster or passive spells is out. When you level up your base stats go up and if you want extra challenge you could play the game without leveling up and for a price you can respend your points on new spells and abilities. The game does something crazy it makes it fun and gives you a reason to kill over 1000 slimes. You would want to kill the slimes for exp, money, collectibles, cards, crafting items, and even if you already have these you can sell them for money and give them to other players. And the best part is killing slimes is fun they get smarter the more you kill and if your not careful even easy monsters can hurt you.

The story is great it is funny, full of references to games like legend of Zelda other games anime movies etc. The story is interesting enough to watch a few times but thankfully you can skip it if this is your 20th time playing the game.

The game has fair DLC there is a 5 dollar hat DLC that is honest that if you play 5 dollars you will give the devs more money so if you want to support them you can. There is no cheap DLC that gives players an edge like golden armor swords or unfair things like that.

The games multiplayer is great and there is little lag for me and you can play arcade, the story, VS with other players and its not like the game needed that because the game is fun just playing by yourself.

So do I recommend this game YES it has great challenge, it has some of the best replay value I have seen in a story, the gameplay is great  the collectibles are fun and worth getting, the multiplayer have 3 fun modes VS, story and arcade ( you can also play mini games in the story with others) and they are still making the game? It is worth it for sure and when they keep this system add more content, collectibles and things like that this game would be my new favorite game of all time. I really thing you should consider buying this game for a fun game to play buy your self and a fun game to play with friends. the only posible thing that the game could add to make it better would be local multiplayer. the game has good gameplay like castle crashers, replay value and collectables somewhat like â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥mes and a short but sweet story.

Early Access Review

Fun game for what there is at the moment. Though there isn't much content in the story mode which i find strange because this game has been in development for years now and they have only managed to finish two temples and a few zones (then they have the cheek of asking for money to go towards coffee breaks in the form of day one DLC) it's still a great bit of fun and the arcade mode adds a lot of replayability. I can't say i'm a fan of the fact they have placed in a online leaderboards as to me that encourages cheating and there's no way you're going to get the #1 spot unless you too cheat and then it makes it seem pointless to do if you're wanting to take part in the arcade mode for the competitive purpose of beating other players. Though this is and the current lack of content in the story mode (at the time of this build i'm sure this will change in later versions) are my only complaints about the game.

The music and sound effects are spot on and you can tell they have heavy inspiration from older RPG games and has a great nostalgic feel about it. I played through the game co-op with one friend and i have to say the net code is spot on and we had no problems with lag what so ever and the game seemed input perfect along with not being too restricted to where you can go in co-op. You and your allies still all have to commit to going to a new zone before the game takes you all there but you're not bound together when you're in that zone. The gameplay is flawless in design too and you feel like you have all the control over your character and when you â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ up and die it is YOUR fault and not the game's. The game has the perfect balance of fun and challenge and the spells/abilities all seem to have their uses though some seem a lot weaker early game and some also seem a lot weaker later game so it's worth experimenting with the abilities as some may be more usefull early game but end up being weak towards the end.

Highly recommend checking this gem out as it lives up to the hype and i am extremely exited in seeing what they add in future updates.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI have played 5+ hours of the games main story mode with a co op friend and have thoroughly enjoyed it thus far. Along with quipment leaving many diffrent options for how players what to play the game be it all diffrent types of magic, a large assortment of wepons armor and combat quipment such as bows power up potions and stat bonus rings. The visuals and music are great to hear and dont get old on long loops, puzzles are a good challenge, enemies and bosses are fun to fight while still being the right amount of difficult at times. There is alot of good to say about the game and as I play more and the game becomes finalized I will due a more in depth review. If this looks like the type of game you would enjoy I would highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Secrets of Grindea is incredibly fun! I absolutely love co-op RPGs, and this ARPG has potential. It has a Secret of Mana/A Link to the Past vibe, and after trying out the free demo, I immediately bought it. While the game is still in early access, there is plenty to do. Once you run though the story (as far as you can, it's still in development), there are likely still items to craft, a pet to level to increase your stats, and an arcade mode that is challenging and addictive. As of right now, the game has controller support for a wired 360 controller, and you can use software to bind buttons of other controllers to specific keys, so you can make different controllers work (I'm using the PS4 controller) - the game feels great with a controller, so it's definitely worth doing if the keyboard set-up just isn't working for you.

I strongly recommend at least trying the free demo - as there's nothing to lose. It's a relatively small download, and while  you could probably rush through pretty quickly, if you take your time to explore and take things in a little, you'll get a decent amount of content for a demo. The demo can also be played cooperatively, so it's probably worth trying to get a friend or two (or three, if you can) to try it with you!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Note: Review made after playing through around 50% completion of the beta with 2 other friends.)

Secrets of Grindea is an action rpg that takes cues from top down Legend of Zelda games and Secret of Mana games.

You run around, fight monsters, and use hotkeyed spells while wearing cool hats.

The music is well, nothing that stands out to me though. (Yet!)

It features a very large amount of items to collect, craft, and fight with (even in the beta, I feel) and quite a few spells, passives, and skills to play with.

The game's story revolves around you and up to 3 other friends adventuring around the world, gathering gear and fighting monsters so you can become the best hoarder in the whole world.

I can break down the gameplay into 4 types; Boss fighting, Enemy Fighting, Crafting and Exploring/Puzzles.

Now, I wouldn't say the bosses are bad, hell, some even verge into the point of having so many projectiles on the screen you could swear you are playing a bullet hell, and are still well made, but i'd say that the bosses have way too much hp.

Examples of this are the Raging Toy Machine" Boss (I think that is what it is called?) which has too much hp and spams too many projectiles at once to even revive your friends

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Me and my friends absolutely love this game! I have a group of friends and we are always looking on here for new games that we can all play together and we have dedicated many hours into this game. At the moment we have beat the game and are patiently waiting for the next update.

Pros:
Great Graphics
Great Replayability
Challenging
Addicting
great game to play alone or with friends
You can beef up your character's skills as much as you want. there is litterally no limit to how powerful you can be.

Cons:

Gets laggy if there are too many enemies on the screen at once (they keep respawning if you keep killing them which is good if you want items or xp but bad if it causes lag.)

You have to have a seperate save for playing alone than with friends. Whoever hosts the game when you play with the same friends has to continue to be the host every time because the story mode continues from the hosts story. If you wanted to play on your own it will start a new game for you but you will be able to keep your skills and items from the other game with your friends. Alse if somebody else decides to host the game it will also start a new game. This was a bit of an issue because we could not play the game and continue on story mode unless the host was wanting to play as well. We could only play on his terms.

taking forever for them to come out with an update.







But aside from the cons it is a very fun game and I would recommend it to anybody. By far my favorite game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I rarely get this excited about a game, but i absolutely fell in love with this game instantly when i started playing it. So i don't really have alot of negative things to say about it.

10/10 I can't wait to see it finished

It plays alot like seiken densetsu 3 meets Zelda.

Pros:
*beautiful custom maps that flow nicely with the tiling and sprites
*the attention to detail on the sprites is impressive
*the amount of animation really makes the game alot more lively. Every map is loaded with different animations to give each area it's own unique feel.
*the mechanics are perfect, I have no complaints there.
*the option for story and arcade mode
*there is an monster arena!
*good scaling difficulty for multi-player.
*crafting system in place that unlock as you discover new items.
*trophy room to replay boss battles
*fishing, which is nicely incorporated into the arcade mode to help acquire loot.
*summons, pets and familiars!!
*I'm sure I missed a bunch of other things to point out in the game.

Cons:
* it's not finished and I'm impatient!
* to short at the moment, and not enough replay yet. (arcade mode gets dull after a few hours.)

Bugs:
*not really bugs but the gigaslime and peckos animation are the wrong ones in the card index. I think it's a regular slime and the peckos doll for thier animation.

Suggestions:
*Infinite scaling dungeon!! (star ocean style!)
*monster catching and breeding for the arena! (ff10 style!)
*add in the multi-player games asap, even before more single player content to increase replay value. (think Mario party!)
*PVP arena of some kind. Maybe ranked matches with special items people compete for.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

10/10 the only RPG without skeletons

In all seriousness, this game is AMAZING. This is the only game I have ever seen on steam that has a perfect 10/10 rating!

PROS.
-Fantastic artstyle, even though its pixelated, everything flows really nicely
-No limitations, choose any ability you want, whenever you want, and however many you want.
-Fun spells and attacks, make you feel incredibly powerful
-Funny and lovable characters
-PETS!
-Lots of replayability
-Grinding is suprisingly fun
-A good challenge I have not faced in some time
-Overwhelmingly fun multiplayer

Sheesh, that took a while.
CONS.
-Kind of short story mode, but its in early access so it gets a pass (in my book at least)
-Arcade mode is repetetive after some time
-$15 is a bit expensive for some
-Some bosses are just huge difficulty spikes

It actually took me some time to come up with cons. This game is a MUST-BUY!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSecrets of Grindea is a top down adventure game that immediately reminds me of the Legend of Zelda series in it's blend of combat and puzzles. While still an early access game at the time of writing, there is more than enough content to justify the fifteen dollar price tag. With an easy to learn combat system and the lack of distinct classes, combat feels smooth and genuinely fun, as one would hope a game with the term grind" in the title would boast. Likewise

voteText: your close friend Luke

column24: but the problem is that the charcters I found memorable made themselves memorable from the first meeting
column25: whereas all of these less memorable characters have appeared at least twice and still have yet to make any sort of impact on me.\n\nCombat in Grindea
column27: is a very easy concept to grasp
column28: if a little hectic in practice. The Z key is your basic melee attack with whatever is equiped to your weapon slot
column35: and V keys all bind to the various special attacks and spells you pick up over the course of the game. This means that a solid blend of melee and magical combat is more than plausible
column36: although the effort to make that blend work is probably more than a strictly melee or magical style. That being said

column42: and it began to become extraordinarily obvious when I was coming close to the end of the story mode content simply because the majority of the major fights became seriously unbalanced towards solo players. Perhaps it becomes less of a headache with coplayers in the mix
column43: but one particularly noteworthy boss fight required me to keep putting damage on the boss while at the same time destroying remarkably resilient minions that were spewing poisonous gas across the battlefield. Forget to put enough pressure on the boss

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally an Indy that gets it RIGHT.  They have captured the old SNES games 100%.  No cheese, no lameness, no clunky interface, no tryhard here,, just a great title.  My only problem with Zelda III and Secret of Mana is that both games had an ending, they were so good.  Those games are timeless, and the graphics hold through even today due to the art style etc...   Secrets of Grindea continues in thier tradition and I just love it, there are a few throwback references but they don't overdo it (like a lot of games do).   Even though it's still Beta, early access, etc... I hope they continue to produce content in the form of DLC forever.  Thanks.

Gameplaywise, the controller support is spot on, it is very alt tab friendly, the game is only 380Mb, so will probably work on any computer out there.  (I'm playing on a tablet, Surface Pro 3..).  Go for it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What an incredible game!
Secrets of Grindea is a story-driven game (With phenomenal RPG elements!) where you can customize your character's appearance, skills, and talents. While the mechanics are simple to grasp, there are many unique bosses and mobs that require certain nuances to accomplish.
The leveling system works out relatively well. It never feels like an over the top grind (hah) until about halfway through, where it suddenly starts to feel like it takes longer to level based upon the monster EXP.
Perhaps my only real complaint about the game lies in the skill system. They've set it up so that you get silver and gold spell points, where you spend so many silver points before you may only place gold points to further level up a skill. After spending 17 hours in the game, I've only been able to get one skill all the way up with gold points, as you only receive one point every few levels.
Still, you can completely customize your hotkeys, and they made it quite easy and intuitive. Though it is early access, they've already thought of many convenience things that other games miss: equipping cosmetic items for free, pets that increase stats, NPCs that have witty responses, etc.
It's rare you find an unfinished game that leaves you thinking about it even while you're in the middle of working, exercising, and trying to sleep. I'm only sad it isn't finished! 9.5/10

TL;DR - Buy this game. I'd regret not trying it. Smooth graphics, intuitive gameplay, conveniency in the game, and some light humor! Totally worth the price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game (all though in early access) is EXTREAMLY fun.
As a retro gamer this game immediatley appealed to my every sense and need in a relaxing fun game, the game has some extreamly challenging and exciting boss battles and the story is well written and perfectly paced (so far).
the combat and skill system is also extreamly fun to play around with, giving the playe endless combinations of skill combinatons as well there being no one truely overpowered combo, making every character personal to the player who controls them.
This game is also graphically beautiful all be it in a, dare i say it, RPG maker esque style, it still is beautifully coloured and each area is well designed and themed making each area fresh, unique and new.
The story as of yet is unfinished and sometimes the co-op has it's issues with characters getting stuck or becoming unusuable, but all these can be fixed with a quick '' on and off '' action by leaving and rejoining the game.
Even if you do finish the story that is complete for now, thats not all you can then have hours more fun in the arcade mode witch has a great sense of accomplish in leveling your ''town'' as you constantly improve your score by running a new challenge time and time again.
Not up for just battling? then why not pick up your fishing pole and had down to some of the few spots in the world for a spot of fishing and catch some of the wacky fish in each area all unique to the area you catch them in.
Leveling is fun and well balanced making this RPG feel less grind and more find as you search for rare ''Cards'' fpr your collection or items to craft some of those unique weapons.
Not onlly can you fisj and craft but also why not try your had at the treasure hunting?
With clever clues and cryptic riddles to assist you in your hunt!!
If you are anything like a gamer, you will have trouble putting this down for a while as you enjoy and progress.

this game is a solid 10/10 for me and i will on the edge of my seat untill this game is not only finished in development but also finished in my story playthrough and i have conquered that dame arcade mode! >:)

If you don't own this game already, BUY IT, it truely is a steal at Â£10

TL/DR;

Pros

- Spiritual successor to older ARPG titles (Secret of Mana/Star Tropics/A Link to the Past)
- Solid build customization and choices that change gameplay a lot
- Responsive Controls, Xbox controller works fine off the hop with zero third party software necessary
- Good Humor
- Good Multiplayer Experience and Customization
- Decent Musical Score
- Fairly difficult compared to modern games (Tough but fair, it's not quite Nintendo Hard" but close)

Cons

- Default keybindings can be hard on hands
date:
probably want a controller unless you want to custom keybind.
- Menu slightly unintuitive at first
- Crafting doesn't seem to be covered at all in the first few hours or so
- Game is incomplete

does not impact current gameplay though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR: Buy this game. Many references, fun story and gameplay but tough as nails bosses.

[Some minor spoilers ahead, be warned]
What is good about this game:
- Being able to select the visual appearence of one item while keeping the stats of another if you choose. No longer must you choose between style and function. You want a chicken hat with the protection of an iron helmet? you got it.
- So many references. In my 7 hours I have notices 3 Pokemon references, a Mario reference, multiple Legend of Zelda references, 2 South Park references, a LITERAL Gundam boss, a well-known youtuber cameo in character and probably multiple more that I have missed.
- Funny dialogue and interesting characters.
- Impressive variety of skills to learn and base your playstyle on. (Several elements with 3 spells each plus many one and two handed weapon skills)

What is bad/can be improved:
- Menus are a bit annoying. For example if I want to make something and I lack the items needed, I can see if I have enough of item A, if I need more of item B or if I havent discovered Item C, BUT It will not tell me how much MORE of item B I need, which is a bit annoying. The difference between Silver points, Gold points and Talent orbs could also be explained better. I got a fair way into the game before realising what Talent orbs were and that I could spend them.
- Some of the bosses feel a bit like Bullet Hells, and it can be VERY frustrating having to redo bosses over and over again since you keep dying to an onslaught of attacks on the screen. Maybe this is intended and I'm just not used to the difficulty, but I think if it is impossible to beat a boss with 1hp, you are doing something wrong as the boss is becoming less Skill based and more Luck based (such as the Winter boss, where he teleports several times and creates multiple ice pillars while launching fists of snow. He can effectively box you in to a point where you end up being hurt by his fist because you cannot move, or by the spikes as you try to avoid said fist. Or the Present machine where you have 6 presents, multiple bombs falling from the ceiling and several trains moving past).
- Block mechanics can be improved slightly. I find myself taking damage if I drop my shield after an attack, even if the enemy has moved back or the projectile has vanished.

I have high hopes for this game and hopefully this game is finished into the masterpiece it has the potential to be, and isn't another forgotten Early Access game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm very picky about my games, and usually there are always things I dislike, but not in this game. This is a hidden gem and I can't wait to see more of it.

If you, like me, loved all those SNES games like Secret of Mana/Evermore, Terranigma, Zelda, you are going to love Secrets of Grindea. I like everything about this game! Graphics are neat, the combat is challenging but fair and feels pretty balanced across all specs. The bossfights are especially well designed.

Story is pretty much what you'd expect. In the current beta there is already a good variety of scenes (forest, snow, pumpkin/spooky forest, cave, christmas, toy factory).

The dialogues are funny and enjoyable.
Try that demo. Now!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

THIS IS THE MULTIPLAYER RPG I HAVE BEEN LOOKING FOR! A very Zelda-esc game that you can play with friends. Bought after playing the demo, I highly reccomend you give the demo a shot at the very least because this is one of the rare early access games that has been worth while for me.

EDIT* I've now put nearly 50 hours in to this game, purchased the game for two of my friends and currently have about 6 friends who've told me they've enjoyed the game, I've been playing with various people with very few problems. (The only real problem worth mentioning is the ping as it is something that needs fixing; some of my friends with bad connection have had their ping sky rocket in the thousands. But with a stable - decent internet it's fine, (In the campaign you can simply drop back into the game). I believe this is only an issue simply due to the fact that it's still early in it's developement, that is my only real complaint as of the time of this review).

Most of my time so far has been in the arcade mode, (Since the campaign is still in development) it's really been a blast. The arcade mode is essentially a rouge type side game that you can play endlessly, sharpening your skills, asending a randomly generated mountain, while gaining points to build your very own village. (It's also a 4 person co-op like the campaign, did I mention you can earn hats?). The game at is core is flawless, the mechanics are great, the fighting feels exciting, the npc's require some thought and strategy. I absolutely love this game, I cannot wait to see the finished version. This is one of the few, if not the only Early Access game I will ever reccomend (Unless something drastic happens to  current early access trends). If you like retro rpg's with(or without)  friends, please give this game a go.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Secrets of Grindea is an action RPG that hones many aspects from RPGs that I know and love. I will be going into a lot of detail about the game and why I love it so much, so hold on to your seats!

Gameplay

The game has a story mode and an Arcade Mode. The story mode is currently unfinished (along with the Arcade Mode), but the game currently boasts a lot of sidequests and collectables along with the story. I have managed to collect almost all of the cards (the rarest collectables in the game, one unique to all normal enemies) as of the 15th of July and I continue to collect even more in the future when I have the time and patience to do so! The game features many sidequests, puzzles and hidden items to find and collect, which required thinking and pure potential in your combatting skills. Currently, the game is very difficult in its Arcade Mode and Hard Mode of the story.

Arcade Mode is the true challenge of the game and the main feature that people will come back to after beating the story. Similar to many roguelike indie games such as The Binding of Isaac and many more titles, the game offers a mode that offers permanent death and restarting all over again upon death, which will truly test your skills. Many of the enemies are buffed up versions of monsters seen in the later parts of the story, beefed up bosses from the story mode and some completely unique enemies that are not (yet) available in the story mode. For anybody who likes roguelike games, this is for you! This also is a good option to play the game without the story being spoiled for yourself if you would like to play the story from the beginning until the end with no interuptions!

For you bustling people with many friends, both modes offer multiplayer aspects, but more people doesn't come with no risk. More players often means newer moves (at least in the story mode) and higher enemy HP, that truly will test your skill instead of making the game a breeze.

Soundtrack

The soundtrack of the game isn't extremely special, but the music fits the game very well and really creates the mood of the game. Often faster-paced/more upbeat versions of the songs in the story mode are used in Arcade Mode corresponding to the area that they are found in. The music is definitely highly atmospheric and I definitely reccomend the soundtrack for any outer-game listening purposes!

Design/Artwork

The art of the game is very detailed and is drawn to a great extent. All of the places in the game are drawn in photoshop and in good detail. Sprites and other things are done seperately but the game blends in and really feels alive. Many of the animations used in the game are done very well and the artwork to follow the characters are also done to perfection. The game is crisp and looks good all the time!

Overall Rating

I think this game is possibly my favourite game I've played in a very very long time, and the game isn't even finished yet. I would definitely reccomend this game to anybody who wants a good game!

Rating:
9.5/10

+ Great Visuals and Animations
+ Replayability is done very well
+ Challenging compelling gameplay
+ Completionists Lucid Dream

- Some game artwork scaled down and doesn't look as good as the original
- The game isn't out yet, not the full experience yet.

If you would like to form your own opinion, there is also a Demo. If you would like to support the developers more, you can get some higher tiers that unlock some extra rewards for your purchase, including helping development ideas and even your own NPC in the game!

I also run the Subreddit! It's currently under high construction and is not as good as possible, but this will hopefully change soon!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even though this is in Early Access, it is quite polished. Not a bug in sight, and there is plenty of game to sink your teeth into here. I was leary of the price, but its definately worth it. This is a throw-back to some great games of fairly long ago. I definately feel some heavy SNES Zelda and Secret of Mana vibes here. Like those, it also has some fairly heavy MetroidVania elements where you will be backtracking through the open world to access areas you previously couldn't.

Pros:
+Great artwork.
+Great feel to it - it plays really well. Controller support and rebindability is great in this title.
+Music is fitting to this style, and is not generic - it is its own thing.
+Awesome level of RPG character customizability.
+Loads of quests even now. I love the treasure maps. Lots of sidequests, and they are all well done.
+Even though the light 'grinding' humor is there - the game never really feels that grindy (ironically enough lol).
+I love when the characters clothes/hair/etc. is customizable and changes with changing items.
+Storyline is well written - I am not skipping through it yet ;)

Cons:
-Online multi is awesome but I really wish they would add local so I don't have to purchase a second copy for my wife to play.
-Hurry up and finish the unfinished zones already :D !!!

If this sounds like something you would like - I guarantee you will not be disapointed with this even in Early Access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Secrets of Grindea is a neat little game reminiscent of ARPG's like Secret of Mana and Ys: Oath in Felghana. The combat is fluid, more so than that of Legend of Zelda and equipping a Two-Handed weapon does not take away your ability to use a shield.

The character sprites are amazing and dynamic, you rarely find an NPC doing nothing physically as most have a nice implemented action to make themselves seem more lifelike. Ones that you find in-game that do this range from flipping their hair, kicking a wagon, turning a crank, and even sipping tea or sneezing. It makes the world come to life more and each NPC has their own individual character portrait to show that they aren't just faceless boring no-name people in the lush world of Grindea.

Skills take another aspect of the game in that they ARE diverse but there isn't a lot of them. Your main weapons will consist of a sword, either one-handed or two-handed and that is the limitation of your weapons. You will find others such as a bow and arrow while exploring but that is just a side weapon which left me wanting a more diverse weapon system. I wish there were more weapons such as a double headed spear that an enemy NPC had or even another skill branch for the bow and arrow but alas there is none.

The world of Grindea itself is nice and all the sprites are beautiful and amazing, however that does not excuse the games limited exploration. Throughout my playthrough I had tried to explore numerous pathways to other parts of the world only to be stopped by an invisible wall and a text box saying. You can't go there! That part of the game is not yet implemented." This kills exploration as there is only on path you can take instead of being able to explore the world as you like which leads me wanting more.

For the price of 14.99$ this game is not bad
date: and is actually amazing. I just wish that there was more diversity in weapons and one pet peeve of mine is that equipment (such as gloves
hoursPlayed: or armor) does not show to change the characters clothes as if appearing invisible. That being said however
voteText: this game is not worth 15$ but IS worthy of your time as the world of Grindea is still being made
helpfulPercent: hopefully once finished it will be worth its expensive price."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

High quality action rpg fun with a lot of nostalgia tossed in aswell. There really isn't enough I can say about this game, the multiplayer is crafted perfectly, with drop in/out features enemy difficulty increasing with each additional player not just increases in attributes but additional skills for bosses etc.

Very indepth character leveling, allows you to create and mold your hero as you please, so you can find your perfect build. The story mode is probably about 50 percent complete, by the time i reached the end i was really yearning for more. There are tons of collectibles and several mini games including pets. Perfect game for the kind of person that loves additional content after the story, especially those who enjoy some grinding.

For those tired of playing in the story, there is a very well crafted arcade mode that is of course also multiplayer and has almost infinite replayability.

The real seller with this game though is the combat, which takes you back to old school SNES 2D top-down games like Link to the past and Secrets of Mana, but it is so much more then that. Once you find a build you enjoy whether you're just sitting back grinding enemies or facing the highest difficulty challenges, time just flies by.

As you can tell I highly recommend this game. There is a demo available which definitely gives you enough of a taste of the game to understand my high praise.

Early Access Review

Secrets of Grindea is Legend of Zeldas and Dragon Quests lovechild. It's easy to pick up, but hard to master. It makes grinding for items fun as the respawn rates are quick. This game is far from done, but with the amount of grinding for cards and hats ( Not to mention the amount of side quests, pets and other things) this game is definetly worth getting. The Devs are always updating it. Im currently 12 hours in on my first account, finshed the first beta stage of the story and I'm still finding things to do. (There is also a hard but rewarding arcade mode where you have to go through stages or floors battling enemies and bosses) The story is interesting and alot of it has yet to be revealed.
If you have read this far, you are doing something wrong, you haven't brought the game!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nEarly Access: I stumbled upon this game casually browsing steam and immediatly thought the game looked awesome at face value.  I got pretty excited when I saw that this game had a demo (including the multiplayer I might add), I played the demo for about 3 hours with and without a friend, and it hooked me the moment I stepped out into startington.  The music is top tear, the pixel art is astounding, the gameplay is crisp and challenging, and the game world has been the first to charm me this much since The Legend of Zelda Windwaker.  So far, I LOVE this game.  The game doesn't take it self very seriously, but there is still loads of meaning behind what you are doing in a world you actually care about, I want to catch every fish, get every pet, complete every quest, collect every item, and I want to be there to watch the story unfold.  Play this game with a friend and have so much fun that 6.5 hours go by like 60 minutes.  Devs if you keep this up, the game will marvel even it's inspirations (Secret of mana SNES) and (A Link to the Past SNES)  I would 100% reccomend this game right now, even if it's unfinished what has been here so far has been totaly worth the $15, grab a friend or 3, or play solo!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(This review is based solely on the Story mode)
This is an extremely promising 2D ARPG early access game that I absolutely adore. It is by no means close to being finished but it has an incredibly solid foundation. The first thing I need to mention is the art style is phenomenal and the game has one of my favorite soundtracks of any game out there. As I'm writing this review, my character is in the Flying Fortress just so I can listen to the music. The music gives me Final Fantasy vibes that I love. Let me also mention that the art in this game is awesome. The game is full of color and it's a beautiful game to look at.

In terms of gameplay, there are many choices to be made. There are skill sets for 1H or 2H weapons and the magic is divided into fire, ice, earth, and air (which should be called lightning...). There are no classes so you can mix and match between all of these sets (For example, you can be a 2H user that also specializes in ice spells. If you freeze an enemy, you are guarenteed your next physical attack to crit).

So far, there are 2 dungeons in the game that both have very strong themes and art styles. There is not a single part of this game I dread going through. I loved Tales of Symphonia but I HATED some of those dungeons/temples (especially the sewers, oh god). Let me also mention that the second dungeon has a mechanic involving changing seasons that I have never seen before in any game. Watching the whole room change colors is quite the thing to see. My only issue with the dungeons are that they are too short. I WANT MORE.

-There are 6 notable bosses in this game and they are all designed very well each offering very different strategies to conquer them.
-Each type of enemy has a small chance to drop a card which gives your character small permanent bonuses (5% discount at shops, Atk/MAtk/Def buffs, AtkSpd and CastSpd buffs, etc)
-Farming" is very easy in this game. If you kill a group of enemies
date:
stick around for about 2 more minutes fighting enemies and the spawn rate at that location will increase like crazy. There's a room in the toy factory that will spawn endless amounts of presents for you to kill repeatedly. I probably did it for a solid 30-45 minutes and it was great!
-This game also features Arcade mode which is essentially a rogue-like version of the game. It's pretty darn hard but fun I suppose. I haven't played it enough for the purpose of this review though.

I'm looking forward to seeing more updates for this game. Not sure if you want to buy it yet? No biggie
recommended: PLAY THE DEMO!\nThanks for reading! I will update this review once more updates come out."
