reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFor being in only alpha, the game is already really well off and shows a lot of potential. I've done a brief solo run and am currently doing a run with a friend and it's really enjoyable. The abilities have good variety, nothing is particularly overpowered and there's a good amount of mechanics. So far there's a pretty nice variety in side quests, and nothing feels too tedious. My only issue would be how purposely dislikeable some characters are, though this is more of an annoyance than an issue with the game itself. I have really high hopes for this game, and I'm looking forward to continuing my playthroughs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For an as-yet-to-be-finished product, this has to be some of the best $15 I have yet to spend. Let's highlight the biggest appeals:

- Beautiful presentation
- Excellent soundtrack, ambience, and sound effects
- Zelda-like gameplay combined with all the right RPG elements
- Reasonable crafting system
- Fun skills to use and master in battle
- Challenging boss battles
- Pets!
- Fishing! (And other mini-games)
- Nod for humor

One of the biggest issues (if you can call it that) that I have come across thus far would be found in the dialogue (typos, grammar, etc.), but that is negligible and takes nothing away from the experience.

Definitely anxious for this one to be 100%!

-There are 6 notable bosses in this game and they are all designed very well each offering very different strategies to conquer them.
-Each type of enemy has a small chance to drop a card which gives your character small permanent bonuses (5% discount at shops, Atk/MAtk/Def buffs, AtkSpd and CastSpd buffs, etc)
-Farming" is very easy in this game. If you kill a group of enemies
date:
stick around for about 2 more minutes fighting enemies and the spawn rate at that location will increase like crazy. There's a room in the toy factory that will spawn endless amounts of presents for you to kill repeatedly. I probably did it for a solid 30-45 minutes and it was great!
-This game also features Arcade mode which is essentially a rogue-like version of the game. It's pretty darn hard but fun I suppose. I haven't played it enough for the purpose of this review though.

I'm looking forward to seeing more updates for this game. Not sure if you want to buy it yet? No biggie
recommended: PLAY THE DEMO!\nThanks for reading! I will update this review once more updates come out."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Secrets of Grindea is a neat little game reminiscent of ARPG's like Secret of Mana and Ys: Oath in Felghana. The combat is fluid, more so than that of Legend of Zelda and equipping a Two-Handed weapon does not take away your ability to use a shield.

The character sprites are amazing and dynamic, you rarely find an NPC doing nothing physically as most have a nice implemented action to make themselves seem more lifelike. Ones that you find in-game that do this range from flipping their hair, kicking a wagon, turning a crank, and even sipping tea or sneezing. It makes the world come to life more and each NPC has their own individual character portrait to show that they aren't just faceless boring no-name people in the lush world of Grindea.

Skills take another aspect of the game in that they ARE diverse but there isn't a lot of them. Your main weapons will consist of a sword, either one-handed or two-handed and that is the limitation of your weapons. You will find others such as a bow and arrow while exploring but that is just a side weapon which left me wanting a more diverse weapon system. I wish there were more weapons such as a double headed spear that an enemy NPC had or even another skill branch for the bow and arrow but alas there is none.

The world of Grindea itself is nice and all the sprites are beautiful and amazing, however that does not excuse the games limited exploration. Throughout my playthrough I had tried to explore numerous pathways to other parts of the world only to be stopped by an invisible wall and a text box saying. You can't go there! That part of the game is not yet implemented." This kills exploration as there is only on path you can take instead of being able to explore the world as you like which leads me wanting more.

For the price of 14.99$ this game is not bad
date: and is actually amazing. I just wish that there was more diversity in weapons and one pet peeve of mine is that equipment (such as gloves
hoursPlayed: or armor) does not show to change the characters clothes as if appearing invisible. That being said however
voteText: this game is not worth 15$ but IS worthy of your time as the world of Grindea is still being made
helpfulPercent: hopefully once finished it will be worth its expensive price."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An amazing game  that feels like a throw-back to the classic zelda games, like Link to the Past. The controls though simple provides a lot of fun. So many different possibilities for customization so you can make your character unique in each way possible.

What I love about this game is the spells and abilities. You want to use one handed sword? Here have some skills that feels like an extension and takes some time to master. You want to use two handed swords? Have even more skills that are fun to use.

Now for magic,  though it feels a bit on the weak end, it is still fun, especially the fire skills to me. It is also fun to have a little little cloud or some other little summon pet to help you out so you are never alone.

Anyone who loves the classic games like Legend of Zelda or Legend of Mana will love this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I think this game is RIGHT down my alley. Unfortunatly, I have a couple of opinions :/ First of all, I think that pets should be able to help out in fights. Second, I think that Mages are a little OP. Third, there should be SOME form of regen like Health Potions sold at the Alchemy Shop, or some kind of Spell that restores health. Forth, Boars are insanly difficult and frustrating to battle considering they are incredibly fast and deal heavy damage, so you cant easily take them down without heavy damage. It doesn't really help that you have to perfectly time a Quick-Block. Fifth, I found an easy way to exploit the fact that you can cut off the attack recharge by Quick-Blocking. For example, if I were to Attack and Block really quickly alternating, i can attack twice a second and deall about 400 damage per second. I also used a whole lot of differant things that i could label as a little broken. First, Phillip (what I call the adorable little snow monster), I want to know whether or not i shoul consider him broken. I decided to max out Phillip and now hes practically like a second me (^-^)

I'll add more later, but for now, I'd love to see Boar nerfing, and Health Potions in Story Mode.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impressions so far:

Secrets of Grindea is a really good game so far. The battle system reminds of the good times with Secret of Mana and A Link to the Past, the overall look recalls the feeling of Golden Sun and Chrono Trigger.
Got the chills when I got out of town to explore the world. A good sign.

tl;dr
It's Nice.

A bit of obnoxious nitpicking:
- The portraits of the characters (in dialogues) may be not anyones taste. Sadly it isn't mine. (For example, the overworld sprite of the bag is awesome, but in the dialogues it loses it's magic.)
- The Soundtrack so far is reaaally good, except for the first 14 seconds of the Evergrind City music, the first time you get there for the collectors exams. Something about it sounds wrong.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While this game is still a work in progress, for what i have been able to do, this game is epic :D
Dialogue-ish stuff
it has comedy, and stuff that makes sense. +9/10
some comedy get's repeated too much, ie bag and fairy talking -2/10
gameplay
since this game is a work in progress, im surprised how well it works. Boss battles were fun, just the right difficulty (my opinion, don't judge me XD) , which is when you die like, 3 times and then you beat the boss, or you farm for EXP (or grind) , and i love how they give you side quests to make it less linear! +10/10
some quests are very repetitive, but theres not much to vary that kind of thing. -2/10
graphics and art stuff
ah yes, an RPG adventure game. I personally think they should always be detailed, but cartoon-like or pixel-ish, and that's what we got. +8/10
sadly though, lots of games accomplish this but it takes a lot of work to do art -1/10
story
a treasure hunter being his dad and wanting to be like him? ok story +7/10
not too original -2/10
variety
two game modes!!! arcade and story! in arcade you basically have to go through a bunch of floors and kill monsters, and you can expand your home area to get really cool features! in story, it's... a story. fighting, questing, buying, and rage await! 10/10
i do not have a problem -0/10
awards
-great for steam early access +8/100
-solid, fun game for a affordable price +5/100
87/100

so buy it now!!!! or not... (cries in the corner of the room) XD
retail: $15

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is what indie retro games is all about. Forget all those games you get in bundles that claim to be retro greatness, but they are really just posing behind 8 & 16 bit graphics but are missing all the greatness that those eras stood for. Those games try to make you buy their games based on your love for nostalgia. This one hit it on the money!!!!!

Secrets of Grindea!!!! Oh yes, this game has done it all right. This is a game that brings back all the best memories from the classic era, games like Zelda for SNES, Secrets of Mana, and it takes what we loved in those games to a whole new level with modern additions and systems.

The combat is awesome action RPG goodness. Hack and slash, cast spells, dodge, block, aim, it is all here and feels great, tight and responsive.

The class system is that you can be anything you want. use any weapon, buy any skill from any school of magic. Boost defense, boost elements, boost crit, boost certain spell types and so on. Insane amount of depth with limitless combination of ways to build your character.

You can also customize the way you look with different looking hats, shields, weapons that you find and equip throughout the game, its all visible, your hair and skin color and more is also selectable.

Slash bushes, crates, vases, you know we all loved to do that and see what item is inside, could be nothing or something great.

There is crafting, fishing and all kinds of other jobs" that you can do in this game as well. It has multiplayer where friends can join you on your adventure online.

This game has so much greatness and is only in EA. These Devs work hard and love what they are creating and it shows. If you really love retro gaming
date: you will buy this now!!! Stop buying the low quality crap that comes from greenlight for 10 games in a $1 bundle and put your cash down on something you will actually play
recommended: enjoy and be proud to own and say you paid for."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSince this game's in Early Access, and I consider that to be an important point when reviewing such things, I'll simple say that this is one of the most polished experiences you'll have with an Early Access game. It could easily be a year or two before the game's finished, and while there's areas and skills missing, the game itself is open with what's missing. It's one o fthe very few game's I've played where the inspiration (Zelda and Secret of Mana being the obvious ones) does not restrict the game in any way. It's not trying to be those games and the devs clearly have a great vision for the game. I've already put 20 hours in pre-Steam release, so I would say it's reasonable to expect that from the game's current state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I agree with many other reviewers beneath me in that Grindea is an engaging, bugless and smooth rpg that has a definite MMORPG feel with the optional rare items farming that I find incredibly relaxing.

Pros -

*Excellent 2-D graphics without being pixelated as seems to be the norm lately.
*Responsive easy to learn controls that forgive mistakes but only to a point.
*Crafting system makes even weak monsters seem worth killing.
*Boss fights are genuinely epic and satisfying.

Cons -

*Crafting system starts out promising but the lack of items to make in later levels makes it feel gimmicky instead.
*Lack of weapons in general makes battles feel too repetitive after awhile.
*Replay value somewhat hindered in storymode by the increasing costs of changing your talent points, sometimes requiring 30 minutes to an hour of farming to try something new.


All in all I'd say for an early access game this is terrific and if the developers could fix the above issues and perhaps double what is already in the beginning stages...It would be a good I would be willing to pay 40+ dollars for. It feels like an offline MMORPG with Zelda-esque vibes. Great game for relaxing and listening to tunes. I pray it gets better from here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Ok so, the game is great.... the combat is fun, the farming is fun, and I HOPE this game gets to see a full release eventually.

Pros:
Fun combat
Cool skills
Easy to get the hang of
Good enough story
Humor
Arcade mode - Feels like a new game

Cons:
Not enough skills (This is early access, i would assume eventually upon a full release there will be A LOT more options to choose from on skills)
Only about 6 hours of gameplay currently (If your lucky, I was done in 5)
Not enough monster spawns in some areas, the games fun, but i feel a lack of challenge due to only seeing 5-6 monsters  spawning at a time then just demolishing them all with an AoE..

All in all, great game, if you wanna support it get it now, if your looking for extensive gameplay and 40 hours or more of fun, I'd advise u wait, or get it on a sale because its current state is still fun, just lacking for the amount of years spent on developing this so far. im talkin like 5+ years and theres only 5 hours of gameplay so... I'm not expecting too much anytime soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really like the game it reminds me of the old school RPG's. Quite Stable Early Access too ( Beta ).

Combat is fun but sometimes overwhelming ( bloo** bees.... ), skills are looking great and there is something for everyone!

My only concern is that even though the game is fun, you will run out of things to do pretty fast... There are only 3 people working on it and it's been months since I saw new area added and years since the game was available on pre-order on Humble Bundle. Buy it if you don't mind incomplete game but what they have is definitely fun. Also there is ARCADE mode which you can play over and over ! It's challenging and will keep you occupied until they release new content for campaign.

As for Art style it's not for everyone and I personally don't like some of it but that is not going to stop me from enjoying the game. I would like to see my items equiped ( like the shield or armor ) but I understand that this would put too much strain on the animator... oh well.

I do recommend this game if you are into top down view / old school / action RPG's :D
It has online multiplayer! Woo! Up to 4 people as well :D

* Note to the devs : Please add 4 - pack for a cheaper price!

This game is amazing. It's a love letter to the classic ARPG titles it's honoring, crafted by a very capable team. Every rock, tree, enemy, animation, npc cameo, plot twist - every piece of this game is further proof this is a passion project for Pixel Ferrets.

TL;DR - Lovingly crafted + Awesome Gameplay + 4 player co-op + Free Demo = Hidden gem of a game you absolutely must try.

Probably worth the asked price just for the arcade mode on its own. And then you realize there's the campaign.
What can I say ? The combat system is simple to learn, hard to master, with a lot of small things that you can learn to do giving it a large learning curve (blocking in time, attacking at the right frame, etc).
If I had to criticize something, it would be the artworks (not the pixel art, it's amazing), the portraits looks REALLY bad, and I wish we would just have the pixelly models, because they look so much better. If the devs get enough money from early access, it'd be a good idea to hire another artist to make those portraits.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf there's a single game in this world that deserves to be recommended, it's without a doubt Secrets of Grindea. It's still a work-in-progress and there's still a crapload of stuff to do and secrets to find! From farming enemies and bosses to sidequests to finding the pet-items that let you recruit new unlockable pets, there's tons of content in the story mode alone! But if that isn't good enough for you, there's the roguelike arcade mode. I'd compare it mostly to Binding of Isaac, going through randomly generated floors and fighting bosses at the end of each one, unlocking bonuses for your next run. What interests me most, though, is that there are rewards that can be transferred to the story mode as well, such as hats or the INSANELY-DIFFICULT-TO-OBTAIN Fae pet. If you're into all that stuff, this game will have you hooked for a LONG, LONG time. Not to mention they're working on a ton of more content as well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I got a little frustrated while exploring when I first got this game, as I discovered the second half of the story mode wasn't completed yet, but this is an early access game with ACTIVE devs who are constantly working on the game to make it the best it can be. The gameplay is very intuitive and fun, and the story is great. You are a collector, and you explore the world looking for cool loot, when you discover that you bag is a living artifact, created long ago, and he's not the only one. In the temples of this game, you must get the artifact at the end, and it seems repetitive, but the game has different ways of getting you into the temple, and (of the two that are in the game currently) each temple has it's own gimmick that makes it stand out from the other(s).
If you finish the story as it is now, there is an alternate mode which has more of a Binding of Issac gameplay style as you go through randomly generated floors and fight monsters and attain treasure. But there's a twist; As you progress and earn points through playing Arcade mode, your town upgrades and you can do different things in the town.
None of my friends have this game so I haven't gotten to play multiplayer, but if it's as good as single player, I'll love it.
Basically, this game has no class restrictions, so you're allowed to grab whatever spells you want, as long as you have skill points, which I absolutely LOVE. This makes chaining spells with your melee attacks incredibly fun and rewarding, but one con I have with this game is that some spells aren't in the game yet.
Buy this game if you have the patience to wait until ths game reaches its full potential.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is another amazing earily access game, It has A great story with a good amout of humor that will make you laugh out loud. This game also has amazing level design that makes you want to keep playing and playing. The mobs in the game are fun to fight agensts and learn how they work and move, and from the start to the end of the game the mob design gets better and better keeping the game intresting and fun. And once you've killed enough of the mobs you can then move to the MANY Bosses this game has and there are one of the great aspects of this game, the boss disign is amazing, kinda remids me of a Dark Souls boss disign with how you have to learn the bosses and see how to fight them, some are easier than others but i feel as the game progresses in development they will only get better and better. Another great feature of the game is the skill pages. theres so many skills you can pick from to improve your character. I cant really explain it but as soon as you look at it you'll know what i mean. I could talk about how amazing this game is already and they only have two temples and could make as many as they want.                                                                         Finaly all im going to say is that this game is worth the $15 and in my opinion should cost more beacuse theres just so much to do in this game i cant even explain it all in this review. Just buy it or your missing out on one of the better early access games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The charms and mannerisms of Zelda meet the colours and music of Pokemon, thrown together in a modern take on classic action RPG's.

This game is godamn beautiful. A work of art, and I'm able to say this after hardly any time played. Infact, I bought it for myself, and then within 5 minutes had bought it for my partner and friends. Story Mode is great, the bosses are awesome and you actually see yourself getting better at the game as you play (amongst the thousands of deaths).

SPOILER ALERT: Arcade Mode is also pretty awesome and the take on it is unique. You have a small town, and depending on how well you do fighting on the mountain, your town is improved.

I would highly suggest this game even to those of you who perhaps haven't tried a game of this type before. 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wrote a whole thing about how much potential this game has but i deleted it at the last second. So now here is the short version...

This game is already awesome. If the developers keep showing it this much love and add as much content as humanly possible (Weapons, gear, side missions, etc) this could be one of the best top down old school style action RPG's to ever come from an indie developer. Just please make this game as long as possible because it would suck to see such a great game be cut short. It deserves a long campaign, tons of side quests and other things to do because the game is just oozing with potential where it is already.

I have only played for a little while so i will have to add to this once i dive in deeper but i am comfortable recommending this to anyone that is into these types of games now. My rating stands at 8/10 with the possibility of being much higher once developed further.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

**This review is coming from a pure single-player experience** (there is multiplayer)
I have done all of the story mode content there is to do at this time, minus collectibles, as of version 0.600amigo.

Pros:
-Fun combat, lots of skills and perks. You can respec for a doable in-game fee. Smooth and fluid animation.
-Multiplayer, which I did not try out. This can be done in the story mode and arcade mode.
-The environments are awesome, the character artwork could be better, and the music is good, but nothing I see myself humming to.
-Many cameos from other video games. Zelda, RE4, Honeydew, to name a few.
-There's a stable version and a frontline" version. Pretty self explanatory. The latter has more frequent updates (every few weeks) the former every month or two
date:
from my understanding.

Cons:
-The amount of monsters you have to kill and the many hours it takes to get a drop does not line up with an items rarity most of the time. It is not unheard of to spend 4-8 hours killing the same monster all to get a drop that is probably not better than what you already have JUST so you can work towards 100% completion. This is never a requirement
recommended: but the cards you can get in particular offer small permanent bonuses
hoursPlayed: and it can take you anywhere from 30 minutes to 8 hours to find the one that you want.\n-It's short. But the game's not done yet. The current story can be done in about 4-6 hours. Getting collectibles could get you another 10-20 hours
voteText: depending on your luck. Question is
helpfulPercent: do you want those mostly mediocre drops bad enough to spend all that time?\n-Arcade mode as a single player is quite a challenge. I usually opt for the harder options in video games like Kingdom Hearts on Critical but this mode is hard from the get go if you are alone. I would like to see some scaling in difficulty to make it more doable (maybe there already is
votesHelpful: and I just suck.) But if you're looking for a challenge
votesTotal: you've got it here. An option to turn down the difficulty would be nice though.\n\nThese problems can be easily remedied with time
votesFunny: however. The creators are friendly and interactive with their community
commentsCount: and they post frequent updates.\nSo the question is
column16: do I recommend this game? Is it worth the current price of $15.00?\nYes it is. For the amount of playtime I got out of it
column17: for the potential of what it can become
column20: which is sure to add many hours. If nothing else
column21: follow this game. Come back to it later. For an avid RPG fan
column22: this is a game to watch out for."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Vandalism simulator 2015.

All jokes aside, this game is pretty good. As the name suggests, grinding is important because you can gain special items by mass killing certain enemies. The game is short at the moment, but if you take your time and complete everything it has roughly 8 hours of gameplay if you play with 2 other friends.

There are commands in-game that allow you to play around and figure out what tree you want to follow, but I will not give you the commands because it kinda ruins the game. Either way, using commands will not make you a god, and it will not make the game easy. Combat is challenging no matter how you play this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is.... frustratingly good. I played it for a couple days but I was so hooked I just couldn't let go of the controller, it's really excellent ! But at the same time, there is a blatant lack of content for now :
A handful of quest (a small dozen), three temples, five potential pets, around thirty different enemies, quite few crafting possibilities, etc. While it's quite decent, you just finish the current storyline with the feeling you need much more, and the world is really cramped.
That's the only actual flaw I can find in Secrets of Grindea : it needs to be expanded. I literally finished all the content, including crafting and grinding most components, in a few hours. I must admit however that the arcade mode is really fun and can increase the time you spend playing significantly !

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Initial Review:

This game reminds me of the snes rpgs but brings new mechanics to the forefront.  Its as many people have said about it early access however the devs been working on this game for 4 years from what people are saying in the forums and it shows through the quality of the game.

Story mode from what I gather is still lacking about 6 hours in total however it only intends to get better :) and longer as they add more stuff in. as the development progresses I can only see the game getting better.

Arcade mode satisfies my rogue dungeon crawling needs as you have 1 life to get through as far as you can get which is a good time killer if no time for story mode.

Overall the game is very polished and I am glad to play this game as early as I did hope it gets only better :), because this game shows that the dev is very knowledgeable and very concern with quality.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I had pre-ordered this way back when it first started pre-orders. I think this was two years ago? At the time the game only had about an hour of gameplay if you 100% everything. Being a person that understands what early-access is I decided to give the game a while before coming back and trying it again.

Now the game has evolved quite a bit since I last played. They have added on a few features, and the story is far more progressed... and it's awesome. The combat is fun, the dungeons are very well scripted and planned out, and the bosses are exciting and challenging. I'm happy to say the multiplayer is also very well done. I have spent a few hours playing with my wife with little to no issues (One time she couldn't see a boss for some reason)

One of the neat aspects about Grindea is actually the way grinding works. If you stay in one place and kill things for a bit you will see that enemies will begin to spawn more and more frequently. This allows for quick leveling and farming for items. It also means that grinding gets more challenging in that spot. It is well worth it for more than just leveling, enemies can also drop special cards that give your character permanent stat boosts.

I could go on but I think one would really have to play the game to get a good impression. Luckily they have a demo although I don't know how up to date it is compared to the actual game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review ( as of 7/23/15)
Secrets of Grindea is a great throwback to the ARPG genre and takes heavy influence from a lot of games from the SNES era of RPGs. The game is played from a top-down perspective and combat is done in real-time, comparable to Secret of Mana and 2D Legend of Zelda games. If you like the combat in those games you'll probably enjoy Secrets of Grindea.

The skill and customization options in the game are very unique in how much freedom the game gives you as a player. The game gives you several options as far as play styles, but you can mix and match the skills as you desire and create a unique playstyle and skill set for yourself. You're also given 2 cosmetic item slots for your characters to customize your hat and/or face accessory so that you can look good, but keep the stats of much better items instead.

The Pixel art is great, everything looks vibrant and is very reminiscent of the SNES era, but at the same time has a very modern feel. The Music is fits well, and is exactly what you'd expect from most RPGs. The humor and references are great, if you've played a lot of RPGs, you'll really appreciate the games' dialogue and subtle nods to other franchises.

The Arcade mode adds great replayability to the game by adding a roguelike element in randomly generated areas and starting from the beginning if you die, great for those looking for a challenge and wanting more of the game.

Did I mention the game supports (Online) Multiplayer? It does, this game can be even more fun with friends! You can go through the Story Mode or Arcade together and this only adds to the game's merits. Local Co-Op is currently unsupported unfortunately.

At the time of writing this review, the game is in early access and incomplete and Story Mode is a bit short, but I strongly suggest trying out the demo and trying the game for yourself. If you like it, you'll probably enjoy what the full game offers now and in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What can I say? I didn't think I would enjoy it near as much as I actually did. I mean, for a 14.99 Beta I expected some grumps, bumps and bugs but this is an extremely polished early access. There are zones you can't enter, sure, but the combat, story and characters are well rounded and feel complete. I was also extremely happy with the level of difficulty that came with some of the puzzles and bosses. It was a very lovely weekend diversion that I will be constantly revisiting for  more content.

In one word? Omghappynostalgiagleechallengingexcitingrelaxingmmfgoodnesshighlyrecommend.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAfter watching Day[9] play this on his live stream we couldn't wait to play. It's amusing dialog is hilarious to read through, and keeps the progression of the story fun enough to not want to skip to gameplay. The customization in fighting styles between my husband and I became evident right away. I dove into a two handed knight with fire damage, and lightening magic to power up my hits. He went into one handed with evasive skills, and speed. We are excited to see what more comes out of the game, as its hard to find co-ops that are so enjoyable in this style of play. Highly recommend!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nJust made it through the story missions available, as well as a few side things. Gotta say this is really good. I dont usually buy into early access, But this shows a lot of potential. Solid music, good combat, and some pretty good humor make this a great time, and really makes me eager for future updates. There really isnt much to complain about here, but there are a few nitpicks. I noticed a few typos, picking up health orbs is a little annoying (as you need to stand right on top of them to collect them), some of the bosses need a bit of tweaking, and some of the characters artwork could be touched up a bit, maybe smoothed out a bit and varying the facial features, as many characters look similar. None of those nitpicks really take away from what you get here though, a fantastic look into what I hope will be an amazing finished product. If you're into games like the zelda series then this is a great pick for you. Thanks to the developers, you guys are doing a great job.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I mean... I don't really know where to start with this game, other than that it's good. Granted, it's still Beta, and therefor unfinished, I would say this game is close to a Dark Souls level of Difficulty vs Reward, and for the most part, the combat is pretty well done (although it can be a tad frustrating at points.) My only real gripe about this game is that there isn't native controller support (again, still beta...) however with some modifcation to my DS3 Tool, I was able to play this with a controller to which I strongly suggest people trying it this way if Keyboard/Mouse isn't really your style. All things considered with what's already in the game, it's pretty fun, and you'll get pretty significant playtime out of it for your money. Oh, and the character dialogue is actually pretty good. I genuinely laughed and giggled at a lot of the things the characters said, and the way they interacted.

TL:DR - If you're already interested enough to read reviews, just buy it, I doubt you'll be disappointed.

I am glad I purchased this game and will have my partner purchase it as well once its fully released. If she wont, ill buy her it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Vandalism simulator 2015.

All jokes aside, this game is pretty good. As the name suggests, grinding is important because you can gain special items by mass killing certain enemies. The game is short at the moment, but if you take your time and complete everything it has roughly 8 hours of gameplay if you play with 2 other friends.

There are commands in-game that allow you to play around and figure out what tree you want to follow, but I will not give you the commands because it kinda ruins the game. Either way, using commands will not make you a god, and it will not make the game easy. Combat is challenging no matter how you play this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is.... frustratingly good. I played it for a couple days but I was so hooked I just couldn't let go of the controller, it's really excellent ! But at the same time, there is a blatant lack of content for now :
A handful of quest (a small dozen), three temples, five potential pets, around thirty different enemies, quite few crafting possibilities, etc. While it's quite decent, you just finish the current storyline with the feeling you need much more, and the world is really cramped.
That's the only actual flaw I can find in Secrets of Grindea : it needs to be expanded. I literally finished all the content, including crafting and grinding most components, in a few hours. I must admit however that the arcade mode is really fun and can increase the time you spend playing significantly !

Initial Review:

This game reminds me of the snes rpgs but brings new mechanics to the forefront.  Its as many people have said about it early access however the devs been working on this game for 4 years from what people are saying in the forums and it shows through the quality of the game.

Story mode from what I gather is still lacking about 6 hours in total however it only intends to get better :) and longer as they add more stuff in. as the development progresses I can only see the game getting better.

Arcade mode satisfies my rogue dungeon crawling needs as you have 1 life to get through as far as you can get which is a good time killer if no time for story mode.

Overall the game is very polished and I am glad to play this game as early as I did hope it gets only better :), because this game shows that the dev is very knowledgeable and very concern with quality.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Though in early access, this game is super entertaining. It brings back the feel of classic games like The Legend of Zelda, but with the added bonus of your friends tagging along. The story is fun, light, and there are many classic throwbacks that gamers will smile at as they play. Definitely worth investing in to help progress it to completion.

Some more good things; there are a lot of reasons to continually fight spawning monsters, which makes farming experience worth it. From collecting new items, which help to craft better armor and weapons, to making the money, to just gathering xp to expand your skills. (Which there are many of.)

The only downside I and my friend have found, is the magic abilities aren't as useful as the melee abilities. We both wanted to utilize the magic skills but we quickly realized just using our swords was easier and much much faster.

This game is in development so I hope to see some changes to the magic abilities down the road.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Why this is an excellent game
-Smooth combat system.
-Skills are all unique.
-Lives up to its name, you can not grind at all and be perfectly fine.
-Sound track is pretty good.
-A better than avearage story.
-Great comic relief.
-Arcade mode adds great replay value.
-Arena mode is a ton of fun.

Why this game is still in Early Access
-Lacking in # of skills
-Game is kind of short currently- if you are just doing the story the game will take you 2-3 hours, If its your first run it
might take longer. although I think believe in its current state the game is no more then 30% complete. There is so much more  to be added.
- Lacking in some features, but has plenty to keep you entertained for a while.
-Sometimes glitchy
-Ability orbs are meh.


Overall, this game is a ton of fun if you have 15 bucks to toss. Don't let the name full you, this game isnt all grinding.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

No this game is not a grindfest. It's got 2 modes: story and arcade, both can be played solo or multiplayer. Story is a world with waypoints, quests, and little punishment for death in normal mode. Arcade is similar to Binding of Isaac with rooms that lock you in with enemies you must kill.

Really well done game with some quality content, good mechanics, and great multiplayer. It's simply a lot of fun and also challenging. Did have some issues with infrequent disconnects and crashes, but players can join an existing session so it's not too troublesome.

There's a lot of potential here, but the story mode is just too short right now. The game's really nice for early access, and as is would be worth $5-10. You can finish the current incomplete story mode in about 5 hours or less. Hopefully it gets finished in a timely matter.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game needs quite a bit of tweaking.
After only 2 and a half hours of gameplay, not only have I had to restart the game from the begining, but I would have to do it again because half of the quests I do break if I exit and save only to come back the next day and find out that I apparentley I already did it even though the quest is still not done.
Another issue I encountered was that when I saved on my first session playing this game and came back the next day, even though I had all my equipment, all of my quest and story progress had been lost. Pretty annoying if you ask me.
My third and final issue that I found was that half the time while trying to run the game, instead of loading it up straight away like my other games, it wouldn't start up. So after clicking on the desktop icon a couple times, it finally loaded up but not properly. The game's resolution screwed up my screen size and zoomed in on a portion of my desktop in a lower quality without the game even loadind up fully. The taskbar icon for the game was active but the game itself wasn't running at all. It didn't even come up when I loaded task manager and tried to end task it. Manually closing it from the taskbar didn't help either. I tried to get a refund, but of course you can only get a refund for a game if you have UNDER 2 HOURS. Pretty dissapointed because not only could I have spent my hard earned cash on something else that would actually work, but I can't even get my money back.
Overall, gameplay and fighting is kinda generic and well put together, but the amount of bugs in only 2 and a half hours is pretty horrendous.
4/10

P.S. The resolution screwing up when booting up the game may be just my fault because of the small resolution monitor that I play on, but come on:
It's a laptop

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fantastic potential!  Above average story, fun, engaging script, and likable character tropes.  The visual style lends itself well to all aspects of the game.

However, this is a game where combat is the bulk of play; in its current state combat is just a little too clunky for my liking to give this game a solid recommendation.  That being said, much of player control is surprisingly tight and responsive.  The problem is that there are too many zerg-rush rooms to let skillful control shine.  Anemic character reach is punctuated by punishing post-swing recovery, and the mobs of enemies ensure that, whether you hit your target or not, another enemy will likely be shooting you in the back during your recovery frames.  Shield-block input seems sluggish deciding between whether you told the character to strafe with the shield up or to change direction to block the sword about to slash your back open.  Perfect Guarding is just an absolute mess when 4+ enemies are wailing on you.

I'm hopeful this will end up a gem of a game, but right now stay away unless you're interested in playtesting to contribute to its growth.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fun adventure game that plays well, has deep skill trees and combat, a charming atmosphere, and what seems like a huge world to explore.

Unfortunately, it's really poorly tuned right now. Some boss battles are utterly ridiculous with how much is going on. One often finds themselves fighting with the controls - facing the wrong way unable to defend against attacks, dealing with weird angles of attack, skills or spells not triggering, etc.

So while it has a lot of potential, I'd wait until this one is out of early access to insure it's tuned up and polished. It could be an amazing game one day.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its a really well done game, but the current state its in, I recommend waiting before purchasing it. Its not done and some parts of the game feel a bit out of place with the crafting system being hard to come by or just boring grinding. Boss fights are amazing and one of the best parts of the game but is one of the only good parts to look foward to in this game.

The leveling up system feels out of place and I know that the devs wanted a game where you can do anything you want with no class or items that truly make you different with others but honeslty that what makes a good RPG or even games with simular things like WoW, Fallout, Skyrim and etc, hell even Terraria does it well. So many times me and my friends found items that were just better that what we had already so having no other choice we use it hoping maybe it will help us. With No Classes thier no reason to build up to a certain classes or benifits really because at times it seems like your character is no different then the other people who play this because everyone justs goes for something thats good and only the good moves and perks making it kinda pointless when just everyone gets the same â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, taking the varity out of the game and really nothing to say I made this character to my play style or even a cool build".

Money is also Pointless at times and just used to buy junk at the blacksmith because you dont wanna grind or dont even know about the bad crafting system in the game. The crafting system is never really introduce and its just there at times not really showing you anything about it or some of the cool items you can make. Two choices that best describe the crafting system is thats it there use it or don't because you will probly forget about it or don't care.

Story is good
date: fun and amazing but at times its like left 4 dead
recommended: by just walking from point A to point B making it really boring along with the never ending spawning of enemies that just are annoying as hell at times.\n\nThis game brings alot of cool elements and amazing coop gameplay that just make it feel right. I truly want to play this game more but theres nothing atm ( AND THE GAMES NOT DONE ) that makes me want to come back with buddies and play. Its a great adventure but with mechanics that don't feel right but is not afriad to try something new but Im just not sure if it fits the game while this game trys to be more than one genre and even then it hardly fits them. Its a decent game and I see alot of potenial in this and wish that other games took risk with like this at times."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI love this game! I really like its pixellated art style and its level system! Its level system is especially great because of its distribution of normal and gold skill points, basically to level skills (which I may add arent limited to a certain class you can choose any skill or spell regardless!) you need to get skill points but eventually once the skill is a high enough level normal skill points wont work and you need to use golden points to make the skill stronger these golden skill points are much more infrequent than normal skill points this provides a way of making it so that you dont get super strong super fast giving you a much more challenging aspect. Another great aspect of the grame is its great side activities! You can fish, tame pets do fun sidequests, herd chickens, and craft strong weapons and armor! I love the crafting system its simple but still needs a fair amount of grinding for certain items, which is great because its well IN THE NAME and it gives you great satisfaction when you finally craft the item! One of the only complaints I'd have about the game is it only lets you play with steam friends which is ok i geuss but I'd like to be able to play with people online I could make new friends with, not neccesarily for story mode but more for arcade mode, which i may add is a little cruel. Other than what i have already stated I have no complaints I really look forward too the games further development in which something I hope to see is a skill line for the bow and different kinds of bows like there are swords, another thing I REALLY HOPE TO SEEEE is healing! while I understand enemies drop health from time to time I feel health potions would be very useful and would bring more attention to the potions shop in Evergrind, another thing regarding healing I hope to see in the game is a healing skill for the support skill line I personally would really like this because healing teamate would make the game a lot more fun with friends. I hope you find this review helpful and if the developers are reading this I hope they find my ideas helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game is amazing. It plays like a Legend of Zelda/Terranigma sort of classic ARPG. The story and characters aren't super compelling, but are good enough to keep you involved in the game and not detract from the gameplay. Your talking item bag sidekick is great, though. The music is amazing. The combat system and level-up systems are great, there's a lot of customizability for how you choose to play the game. Lots of the options for combat have great synergy between them, and there are no class restrictions to skills, creating a sort of mix-and-match build system that feels really fun.

The only negative disclaimer is that the game definitely isn't finished yet. The content runs out 5-7 hours into the game right now, smack in the middle of the plot. If unfinished content isn't your thing, I would recommend waiting for the game to be completed before buying.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For an early access game, this game is absolutely fantastic. I cannot wait for more of the game to unlock so I can proceed further.

Being an avid NES/SNES player, this game has an element of Zelda (Link's Awakening) into it that I greatly enjoyed. Smooth gameplay, at times frustrating when you aim the wrong way, or the enemy misses your shield but strikes you. Otherwise, I cannot put this game down.

A great RPG element, with tons of skill customization. You want to be a sword wielding mage? JUST DO IT! You want to be a barbarian focusing on pure damage? DO IT! You want to be Knight with a mixture of AOE spells? DO IT! Like I said, you pick what sort of character you want to be.

A def worthy buy.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSecrets of Grindea is an over-head 16-bit style RPG. It implements features like skills that you can upgrade, which allows you to choose what role your character takes (Melee or magic, or both). The devs seemed to focus more on mechanics and gameplay rather than storyline. But, it's not all hack-and-slash, there are puzzles through out the game, some that you have to complete, some not. The combat is good in-that you can't just spam the attact button since that'll probably get you hit, the game kind of forces you to utilise skills that you've chosen when in combat, which is a good thing because it keeps the player on their toes and makes them think about what their next move will be. Overall, I'd recommend it to anyone who likes these sort of games and not just games like CoD and CS:GO and even though the game's in beta, it feels like a completed game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love the older feel to this game; it reminds me of the many similar games I used to play growing up (Legend of Zelda, Chrono Trigger, Secret of Mana...). It also brings a lot more creation to you for your character, allowing you to customise your appearance and choose the way you level your abilities/skills (one of the main reasons I love RPGs). Not to mention that you can play with 3 other people, who make their own unique characters too. My brother and I bought this game yesterday and have had a blast playing it together, which was quite helpful as some of the boss fights would be a real pain by myself; farming for crafting materials too.

Of coarse it is still in the beta and there are a few paths that are blocked off as the next map has literally not been added to the game yet, but my concern at this point, is worry for how big this game will be; My brother and I haven't played that long (though it has been a few hours) and it appears that we are about halfway through the story. You can have up to nine characters, but there isn't a whole lot you can do different between plays (you can make it more difficault and play alone for a real challenge or try a different build for your character) and I fear I may get board once I've finished the game once or twice, but thats just me; others might like shorter games.

Having said that, I have no idea what the creators plan and what plot twist there could be, which could have this game spiralling much deeper and longer than it appears; my hope is for a game at least as long as the games I mentioned above. It is in beta after all, and so far I love this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PERMANENT BETA
PERMANENT BETA
Yesterday Planetary Annihilation released a standalone game that completely replaces their older product. The game was successfully Kickstarted and went through Early Access where it attracted endless negative reviews; missing features, promises that weren't kept and deadlines that weren't met. The cynical among us might suggest a completely new product means a fresh slate for Steam reviews - but it's a damning indictment of a company's misuse of Early Access.

It's a shame because, for the most part, Early Access has been a phenomenon, allowing games to grow and developers to get real feedback on what's working and what isn't and make changes based on those player responses. Secrets of Grindea has recently hit the Early Access scene and, after a successful demo launch earlier in the year, stands out as a shining example of development done right.

Secrets of Grindea is a 2D RPG in the vein of the older Zelda or 'Of Mana' titles. it has the same charming art style but has a quality of animation that gives the whole game a modern feel, that unfortunately doesn't translate especially well into screenshots. The game focuses on a young boy leaving his village to become a man (stop me if you've heard this one before) and to do so he must first collect his sword and shield and make his way to the nearest town.

On the way you'll learn the basics of combat and get a real feel for how exceptionally well animated Secrets of Grindea is. The sway of a cloak as you dash, the hunched shoulders of a defensive position and the theatrical swirl as human enemies pirouette to the ground in defeat.

The premise of the game is, aside from killing and leveling up, that you are a collector. A type of champion who's tasked with chronicling and cataloging things within Grindea's gorgeous and vibrant world. There's a hint of Pokemon about it all, but Secrets of Grindea wears its influences proudly; and why not? This is an excellent reimagining of some classic ideas and franchises.

The levelling up system itself is more reminiscent of Diablo than any other franchise. As you level up you get skill points which you can put into various areas; magic, defense, skills etc You can unlock new, castable abilities which subsequent points will improve, or level up several of your passive skills. It's adequate, though I'm yet to come across a level up system that I could ever describe as anything other.

I've finished all the content available in Secrets of Grindea's Early Access build outside of the game's Arcade Mode which I'll delve into when the full release arrives. As it stands, though, I would have no reservations about recommending Secrets of Grindea to anyone. It's been a while since a game has been so whimsical, light-hearted and, as simple as it sounds, fun. It's gorgeous, colourful with a stellar soundtrack and is more than an homage to 16 bit classics. This is a faithful re-imagining of the tropes of old with a modern shine and it does it so much better than everyone else.

http://www.permanent-beta.net/previews/2015/8/19/early-access-investigations-secrets-of-grindea

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So my wife and I just finished the story to it's current state.
The game is still missing a good bit of content, but we managed to get 10 solid hours of enjoyment out of it already.

Pro:

- Co op seems to work pretty well, sometimes desync here and there with summons or pets, but nothing major.
- We enjoy the recipes and fish collecting. Finding new pets seemed neat at first until we realized they all start at the same stats, so changing pets just sets you backwards.
- Love the hats and the masks, wish you could see the different shoes on your character.
- Fun story :)
- The open skill system with added effects at later levels.
- Love the music, very nostalgic.
- The card collecting adding stats was a GREAT way to make a seeminly simple mechanic actually worth using.

Cons:

- Some of the boss battles feel cheap, the hydra comes to mind as they will wait to attack the only time you have to attack the one that's on the ground, so you just end up running around in circles with your thumb up your rear.
- Some boss fights have attack timings that rely more on lucky character placement as you can't react fast enough to block it or avoid it. They are still fun, but we def. ended up fighting Winter like 5 times :p.
-

- More recipes, more gear, more skills, just need more content.

Overall, both my wife and I thoroughly enjoyed what this game had to offer so far, and were glad to support the developers and look forward to future updates.

P.S. Grand Master Ivy is a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Have you ever wondered what a Zelda game with Terraria aspects to it would be? Well, the Secrets of Grindea is basically that, but better. SOG as I call it, starts as you as the silent protagonist in the world of Grindea, a fantasy world with a main story, and a bunch of side quests. This game is yet another early access game, but there is a ton to do here, just in the Beta version. There are 2 main modes so far. There's the main story campain, that you can eather play alone or with friends   online on a co op game. And there's Arcade Mode where you and friends can go through dungeons, collect treasure, weapons, do challenges, and kill enemies, to see how far you get. If you die you start over, so you have to do it all again, but  you can get escence statues, that you can use to purchase upgrades, to give you an easier time. Honestly, I think it's annoying sometimes, starting all over each time, but it's still fun regardless.

SOG is a very good game, and I absolutely love it, even in Beta, and I can't wait to see what the full game will be like! It's fun with friends, and great alone.  For $15 I still think it's worth the price, and I usually don't think that for other early access games.

The Secrets of Grindea gets a 9.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent action rpg. Like a cross between Ys and Zelda. Very good gameplay 10/10. The combat mechanics are very well thought out, many enemies cooperate and you have to plan your attacks accordingly. Bosses will make your heart race, some of them reminds a bit of bullet hell shooters. Animations are very nicely done, music is good. Story seems pretty standard for this kind of game so far, not exactly Chrono Trigger level, but its engaging enough to want to know what happens next and theres lots of funny moments. Theres a simple fishing minigame, mainly for providing food to your pets, who gives different permanent buffs depending on what you feed them, and some not so hard puzzles.

I dunno how much of the game (story mode) is finished atm, mabye 1/4? (hope its less :p ) The content that is in the game seems 100% done and everything is working great, very polished, unlike most early access games... Didnt notice any bugs. As of now theres about 10-12 hours worth of the main game (mabye a bit less if you play on normal and just blaze through) + xx hours of arcade mode, wich is a sort of semi random series of rooms" where you try to get as far as possible before you die while building up your character on the way
date: and get your high score in the global ranking
recommended: great fun. Havent tried it in co-op mode yet so cant comment on that.\n\nI can confidently recomend this to anyone

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you don't mind a grind like the title suggests, the gameplay is crisp and enjoyable, the crafting is fun, and the boss fights are challenging enough. The skillcap is high enough to feel that you can outplay most challenges.

As I'm currently nearing the end of the available content (?) I think I can say that the game is already enjoyable and worth buying just to support the devs in finishing their excellent product.

-Should you buy this?

If you like Zelda, crafting, enjoy tight skill windows, etc, and don't mind a grindy game, then yes!

-Should you not buy this?

If you don't like a heavy grind. That's basically the only con in my book is it can be overly grindy at times.

Strongly recommend!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI love this game! I really like its pixellated art style and its level system! Its level system is especially great because of its distribution of normal and gold skill points, basically to level skills (which I may add arent limited to a certain class you can choose any skill or spell regardless!) you need to get skill points but eventually once the skill is a high enough level normal skill points wont work and you need to use golden points to make the skill stronger these golden skill points are much more infrequent than normal skill points this provides a way of making it so that you dont get super strong super fast giving you a much more challenging aspect. Another great aspect of the grame is its great side activities! You can fish, tame pets do fun sidequests, herd chickens, and craft strong weapons and armor! I love the crafting system its simple but still needs a fair amount of grinding for certain items, which is great because its well IN THE NAME and it gives you great satisfaction when you finally craft the item! One of the only complaints I'd have about the game is it only lets you play with steam friends which is ok i geuss but I'd like to be able to play with people online I could make new friends with, not neccesarily for story mode but more for arcade mode, which i may add is a little cruel. Other than what i have already stated I have no complaints I really look forward too the games further development in which something I hope to see is a skill line for the bow and different kinds of bows like there are swords, another thing I REALLY HOPE TO SEEEE is healing! while I understand enemies drop health from time to time I feel health potions would be very useful and would bring more attention to the potions shop in Evergrind, another thing regarding healing I hope to see in the game is a healing skill for the support skill line I personally would really like this because healing teamate would make the game a lot more fun with friends. I hope you find this review helpful and if the developers are reading this I hope they find my ideas helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is really great. Do you remember what it felt like when you first fired up Zelda: A Link to the Past? Were you a kid then? Did you have this sense of adventure and wonder as you didn't want to put the game down and complete the content? This game really captures that feeling.

Everything in this game feels well done, professional, polished and not amateurish which are rare attributes in a lot of green-lit games. This game is worth $15 right now and will be worth more when they add additional content. In fact, I hope they add a significant amount because there is at least one dev on this team who knows how to make games and it shows.

If you're on the fence but you liked and played SNES games, just get it.

Early Access Review

This game was purchased to me by a friend, we played it together.
It's (as the name suggests) kinda grind reliant, the grinding itself is pretty fun though! Monsters/enemies are well-made. Good aesthetics, not too easy and not too difficult.
There's plenty of secrets and tricks to discover as well.
The crafting system is actually pretty decent, it's quite easy to figure out, though there's no information saying item dropped by X" - You kinda have to remember which enemy drops what
date: but the names are quite relatable!\n\nI've played it solo as well and can be fun
recommended: but I think with good company it's more enjoyable
hoursPlayed:
although you'll have to fight for loot haha! (loot settings can be altered by host)
I'd recommend this game if you like exploring and crafting.

Not to mention the art style is incredibly cute :) (reminds me of Maple Story)"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nCurrently, I'm about 7 hours into this great game.  Talk about a refreshing one! Lately, I've been having a hankering for some nostalgia, but at the same time I really didn't want to play something I've already played before. This game was able to satisfy both of those aspects for me. While it is still in beta, this game actually really stands up for itself! Customizeable characters (hair style, hair color, skin color, scarf color, shirt color, and pants color), hack and slash, level up system, upgradeable skills, crafting, clever dialogue, addicting gameplay, and difficult bosses keep you addicted as you realize you've lost a few hours of your life. No ragrats!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Classic style RPG filled with challenging puzzles and boss fights, an interesting combat system, and an addictive soundtrack.

The co-op is amazing, and runs very smoothly with the new Steam connectivity patch, no more direct IP and port forwarding nonsense.

The combat is clean, and challenging. You can't just hack and slash your way through dungeons. You have to think about your foes weaknesses and your strengths and play on that. The boss fights themselves can sometimes be considered a puzzle.


Overall the storyline is fairly average(and at this moment incomplete), but the creators have put a lot of effort in making sure the dialogue is complete and and have even slipped in some comedy to give you a laugh every once in awhile.

Good game overall with lots of potential, canâ€™t wait to see what comes next!

I've been playing for about 2 hours at this point, but wow I am impressed! This game reminds me of the SNES type action-RPG's that I loved growing up. While the game is still in development, I can't wait to see how it shapes up. For anyone who is thinking of buying this, it is important to note that there are two servers. The first is the stable server that you get access to with initial purchase. This is the one I started playing on before I realized there was another server: Frontline. Which is the beta server and has the latest updates and much more content.

So far this game is exactly what I've been looking for in a retro" style game. Currently 5/5. Will adjust score when game is released as a finished product."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you don't mind a grind like the title suggests, the gameplay is crisp and enjoyable, the crafting is fun, and the boss fights are challenging enough. The skillcap is high enough to feel that you can outplay most challenges.

As I'm currently nearing the end of the available content (?) I think I can say that the game is already enjoyable and worth buying just to support the devs in finishing their excellent product.

-Should you buy this?

If you like Zelda, crafting, enjoy tight skill windows, etc, and don't mind a grindy game, then yes!

-Should you not buy this?

If you don't like a heavy grind. That's basically the only con in my book is it can be overly grindy at times.

Strongly recommend!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you have a friend you really like playing with online, I really cant say anything else than WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR? This game is wonderful, the combat is beautiful, the music is awesome, and the humour put into it actually wants you to read the text and kinda follow the plot, I was really sceptic to this game when we started and then you start to get the feel of the game.

We ended up finishing the story mode that's currently out as it is early access still, and we've sat for about 8 hours if not more. The combat is very satisfying, especially with controller, I havent tried with mouse and keyboard, but with controller everything is smooth and awesome. The bossbattles are extremely wild and incredibly satisfying when you win, the battles are quite hard on normal difficulity, and when you die you dont really feel cheated or that anything is unfair, you just kinda laugh and get back at it. The graphics are a perfect 10/10 for the type of game it wants to be. beautiful particle effects, and animations. Some of the characters you meet are quite memorable, because of their attitude, or just humour.

If you want something to play by yourself or with up to 4 friends , thats smooth, fun, challanging, and awesome, then this is the perfect game, and its not that expensive. I really reccommend this game even tho on the screenshots and video it might not look that extraordinary, but trust me, its fantastic. 9.5/10 from me.

This game, to put it simply, is amazing. The animations are smooth, the storyline is enticing, and the combat, surprisingly, is quite interactive.

The ability to pick and choose whichever skills you want with no restrictions really allows you to create your OWN character. There is no optimal" skill set
date: you just find the one that works for you. The game is extremley challenging on HARD mode
recommended: requiring players to strategize on every single fight; giving you a great feeling of satisfaction after clearing a room. Speaking of feelings
hoursPlayed: the gameplay intertwined with the storyline does an outstanding job at provoking feeling within you. Satisfaction

column19:

Pros: Everything

Great fun so far and my son loves watching me play since I named the main character after him.

I've been looking for an enjoyable 2D RPG for some time as it seems like most game devs have all but abandoned the genre (yes, it's a genre, not a technical limitation).

So far, I'm really enjoying the flow of the game.  I'm fairly excited to play more of it.  Story is cheeky and fun.  Mr. Bag is hilarious.  Looking forward to throwing more time into this game.

Great work, devs, you've made this guy happy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Classic style RPG filled with challenging puzzles and boss fights, an interesting combat system, and an addictive soundtrack.

The co-op is amazing, and runs very smoothly with the new Steam connectivity patch, no more direct IP and port forwarding nonsense.

The combat is clean, and challenging. You can't just hack and slash your way through dungeons. You have to think about your foes weaknesses and your strengths and play on that. The boss fights themselves can sometimes be considered a puzzle.


Overall the storyline is fairly average(and at this moment incomplete), but the creators have put a lot of effort in making sure the dialogue is complete and and have even slipped in some comedy to give you a laugh every once in awhile.

Good game overall with lots of potential, canâ€™t wait to see what comes next!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you don't mind a grind like the title suggests, the gameplay is crisp and enjoyable, the crafting is fun, and the boss fights are challenging enough. The skillcap is high enough to feel that you can outplay most challenges.

As I'm currently nearing the end of the available content (?) I think I can say that the game is already enjoyable and worth buying just to support the devs in finishing their excellent product.

-Should you buy this?

If you like Zelda, crafting, enjoy tight skill windows, etc, and don't mind a grindy game, then yes!

-Should you not buy this?

If you don't like a heavy grind. That's basically the only con in my book is it can be overly grindy at times.

Strongly recommend!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So my wife and I just finished the story to it's current state.
The game is still missing a good bit of content, but we managed to get 10 solid hours of enjoyment out of it already.

Pro:

- Co op seems to work pretty well, sometimes desync here and there with summons or pets, but nothing major.
- We enjoy the recipes and fish collecting. Finding new pets seemed neat at first until we realized they all start at the same stats, so changing pets just sets you backwards.
- Love the hats and the masks, wish you could see the different shoes on your character.
- Fun story :)
- The open skill system with added effects at later levels.
- Love the music, very nostalgic.
- The card collecting adding stats was a GREAT way to make a seeminly simple mechanic actually worth using.

Cons:

- Some of the boss battles feel cheap, the hydra comes to mind as they will wait to attack the only time you have to attack the one that's on the ground, so you just end up running around in circles with your thumb up your rear.
- Some boss fights have attack timings that rely more on lucky character placement as you can't react fast enough to block it or avoid it. They are still fun, but we def. ended up fighting Winter like 5 times :p.
-

- More recipes, more gear, more skills, just need more content.

Overall, both my wife and I thoroughly enjoyed what this game had to offer so far, and were glad to support the developers and look forward to future updates.

P.S. Grand Master Ivy is a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥.

Great work, devs, you've made this guy happy.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSecrets of Grindea is an over-head 16-bit style RPG. It implements features like skills that you can upgrade, which allows you to choose what role your character takes (Melee or magic, or both). The devs seemed to focus more on mechanics and gameplay rather than storyline. But, it's not all hack-and-slash, there are puzzles through out the game, some that you have to complete, some not. The combat is good in-that you can't just spam the attact button since that'll probably get you hit, the game kind of forces you to utilise skills that you've chosen when in combat, which is a good thing because it keeps the player on their toes and makes them think about what their next move will be. Overall, I'd recommend it to anyone who likes these sort of games and not just games like CoD and CS:GO and even though the game's in beta, it feels like a completed game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For an early access game, this game is absolutely fantastic. I cannot wait for more of the game to unlock so I can proceed further.

Being an avid NES/SNES player, this game has an element of Zelda (Link's Awakening) into it that I greatly enjoyed. Smooth gameplay, at times frustrating when you aim the wrong way, or the enemy misses your shield but strikes you. Otherwise, I cannot put this game down.

A great RPG element, with tons of skill customization. You want to be a sword wielding mage? JUST DO IT! You want to be a barbarian focusing on pure damage? DO IT! You want to be Knight with a mixture of AOE spells? DO IT! Like I said, you pick what sort of character you want to be.

A def worthy buy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is excellent but suffers some problems.

Secrets of Grindea is a Zelda style action RPG with levelling.

Edit: Originally I had a paragraph here stating that the game is way too hard, but then I learned that I set the game to hard" when I started - so to complain about that would be dumb :P. The next paragraph still stands though
date: regarding some of the hard parts of the game.\n\nI think this could be remedied with a pretty simple fix - another branch of magic that lets you heal/buff. The game has no health potions
recommended: so you're at the mercy of health drops from enemies.\n\nAlso
hoursPlayed: it suffers from a lack of content. This isn't a hard negative - it's still in early access! From the looks of things
voteText: the developers have a ton of content planned. As far as I've gotten though
helpfulPercent: there are very few side quests or optional dungeons
votesHelpful: and not a lot of equipment variety.\n\nProbably the most disappointing thing is that
votesTotal: after I started a multiplayer playthrough with my friend
votesFunny: we don't both get Monster Cards together. Loot in general is shared evenly (in Round-Robin sharing) but monster cards take so long to get that it is very very disheartening to not get one when it drops and your friend gets it.\n\nMy last negative point  - the soundtrack is only mediocre. Lots of games these days have phenomenal soundtracks
commentsCount: so you almost expect it when a game hits "Overwhelmingly Positive". I think this game can get there - but the soundtrack isn't helping. It's not bad
column16: but it's not good enough.\n\nBut the positives. Oh man
column17: I could go on and on. So I will.\n\nThe first thing is the graphics - it's BEAUTIFUL. Some of the best pixel art I've seen in years.  Your avatar can be customized with a ton of different styles and colors
column18: and they all look great. Every enemy and character is gorgeously animated . The environment is amazing. This game is just overflowing with great visuals.\n\nThe gameplay is a TON of fun. Combat is great with a few snags in my opinion. The skill system lets you pick whatever skills you want first
column19: with 4 different magic elements and physical skills to choose from. There's a good amount of variety in builds and if you have (quite a lot of) money you can respec all your skills. You can stagger enemies and get bonuses from precise shield blocking. Sometimes if you attack too quickly
column20: it eats your input and you just stand there
column21: so that can be pretty annoying.\n\nYou have a bottomless bag (No inventory management! 5 Stars right there). Enemies drop stuff ALL THE TIME and its really satisfying to collect it all. And there's a ton of stuff to collect. It's a grind-lovers dream. You can refight bosses to get their rare drops.  Every enemy in the game has an ULTRA-RARE drop as well
column22: which can be fun to farm for.\n\nThere's a crafting system that lets you build new equipment with all the drops you collect. IMO the game needs more mage equipment - I still only have 1 wand
column23: from the beginning of the game.\n\nThere are so many well-done mechanics in this game - collecting things is a blast
column26: good variety of enemies. It's a ton of fun to play and I can't wait for the full version to come out.\n\nAll in all
column27: I highly recommend this game to anyone that likes RPGs or the Legend Of Zelda series."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nReally fun and very addicting game! Also pretty underrated as I dont see this game get a lot of attention. This game is a nice throwback to old school RPGs and plays like a zelda/secret of mana type of game. This game is still in early access and not finished however I highly recommend this game still because you can get plenty of hours of gameplay trying to collect every card, discover every monster/item, and also the main quest itself which is a great storyline, plus CRAFTING. It also has an unforgiving roguelike arcade mode which is very challenging. Did I also mention you can explore grindea with friends? I havent played the game coop yet but will eventually with my best friend but if you have friends to play this game with, you can do that too! Support the developers of this game!
